## 4.1. Decoding Algorithms
The clinical standard for RPH control is based on the use of two sEMG channels, with the electrodes placed superficially on antagonist muscles. The envelope of the signal is extracted so that the user can control the closing and opening of the RPH by modulating the amplitude of their muscle contraction. When the amplitude exceeds a certain threshold, the RPH will move depending on which muscle was activated. Companies are offering more DOFs, using cocontraction to

cycle through different types of grasps (e.g., Ottobock's Michelangelo hand). However, this type of control is highly nonintuitive and gives only low dexterity to the user. An alternative to this direct control approach is based on pattern recognition methods, extracting hand-crafted features to characterize the signal in a discriminative way (e.g., the signal root mean square, wavelength, and zero crossing) and classify the type of grasp intended by the user. This solution has become robust enough to reach the market (the Coapt system and Ottobock's Myo Plus). Using 2-12 bipolar sEMG electrodes makes it possible to obtain good classification rates for different kinds of grasps, with 90-95% accuracy for 4-12 classes and up to 75% for 50 classes (68-72).

Using a similar electrode disposition and classification method, other groups showed the possibility of decoding single-finger movement using the classification of flexion or extension (73, 74). Recently, Bhagwat & Mukherji (75) showed single- and multifinger classification of 15 different movements with 99.79% accuracy. Researchers are also working on proportional control instead of classification, which makes it possible to decode several DOFs (e.g., wrist and finger movements) simultaneously and proportionally (76, 77). This type of control offers continuous position control. Several studies have also shown that single-finger proportional control is feasible, with good results (78, 79).

As an alternative, nonbiomimetic EMG decoders have been developed that rely on the subject learning inverse maps to relate motor outputs to arbitrary control variables (80). Using an abstract decoding cursor control space, subjects can learn to modulate their EMG activity to reach different targets arranged in a center-out task in order to trigger various grasping movements (81). Dyson et al. (82) recently validated these results on amputee participants; they showed that after training, the difficulty of the tasks could be increased, improving the possibilities for robotic hand control.

With only a few electrodes placed on muscles of interest, the accurate positioning of the electrodes requires anatomical knowledge; indeed, the type of amputation (congenital or traumatic), the surgical procedure, and the time since amputation (83) could influence the muscle anatomy and make the placement of the electrode tedious and specific to individual subjects. Moreover, a small shift in electrode placement can disrupt the pattern recognition algorithm (84). T o tackle these issues, several authors have proposed HD-sEMG, which consists of a grid of closely spaced electrodes, as an alternative solution. The large number of electrodes allows information to be recorded from a large part of the subject's forearm.

HD-sEMG signals offer high spatial resolution, and recorded signals can be interpreted as spatial images of EMG activity. Using this image representation of EMG data, HD-sEMG is robust to small electrode shifts (85). Boschmann & Platzner (85) used a structural similarity index, borrowed from the computer vision field, on HD-sEMG images combined with a simple one-against-one nearest-neighbor classifier to decode wrist and hand motions. Similarly, Stango et al. (86) used a variogram of images (a measure of the degree of spatial correlation, used mainly in geostatistics) to classify wrist movements. Both groups showed that their methods, which use spatial information from the images, performed better or similarly to the classic feature extraction approach. Moreover, their strategies improved the robustness to electrode shift and electrode number. The use of several spatially close electrodes makes it possible to decompose the EMG signal into its constituent motor unit action potential (50, 87). Kapelner et al. (88) investigated this approach, decomposing EMG signals to extract motor unit activity from forearm muscles during wrist motions. Recently, Dai & Hu (89) showed that an approach consisting of finger joint angle estimation, combining classification for finger selection with EMG decomposition into motor unit activity, outperforms a standard amplitude-based approach.

We observe a paradigm shift from feature engineering to feature learning using raw data as input for deep neural networks. Studies have shown that combining this deep learning approach with HD-sEMG offers better performance than hand-crafted features in both grasp classification

(90) and simultaneous single-finger and wrist movement classification (91). Deep learning has also shown good results with a smaller number of electrodes for grasp classification (72) and regression of arm or wrist motions (92, 93).

This approach permits both high dexterity and robustness, with unprecedented performance. However,one of the major difficulties of the deep learning approach is that it requires an extensive data set for training. For example, the deep learning used for the ImageNet challenge in 2012 used 1.2 million images for training on 1,000 categories (94). In the context of hand gesture recognition, generating tens of thousands of examples for a subject is not a viable option.

A possible solution could use domain adaptation [often called transfer learning in the EMG literature (95, 96)], by leveraging data acquired from several subjects to enhance and accelerate training for a new user. Indeed, the aim is to use information from a database of several source domains and adapt it to a target domain (the end user) with a small number of samples. Authors generally apply deep domain adaptation (domain adaptation combined with deep learning) by pretraining a deep neural network and fine-tuning it with a few repetitions of movements by a target subject. The main idea is that gathering the recordings of several participants can meet the necessary conditions to learn a general mapping of all users' sEMG signals.

Using this idea, Côté-Allard et al. (97) showed that their deep model was able to learn the features and significantly enhance the performance of deep networks on out-of-sample gestures. Using HD-sEMG and deep learning, Du et al. (98) also showed an unsupervised deep domain adaptation method that incrementally learns from data during a new session without explicit calibration of gestures. Consequently, deep learning offers a particularly attractive context from which to develop deep domain adaptation algorithms to leverage interuser data. This approach can increase decoding performance, improve robustness to electrode shift, and reduce the number of repetitions needed during training (99).

As seen in this section, the search for new EMG decoding algorithms that go beyond thresholdbased detection is an active field of research. Phinyomark & Scheme (100) and Khamparia & Singh (101) have reviewed recent research in EMG pattern recognition methods.

Machine learning in the field of computer vision and object recognition has shown outstanding results using deep learning and is already used commercially by many companies. Some deep learning algorithms based on a pretrained network are now usable without any fine-tuning (e.g., self-driving cars). However, bio-signals are intrinsically different from images and need adaptation. More important, the amount of labeled EMG data available to effectively train deep networks might not be sufficient to capture the evolution of the signal over time (electrode displacement, skin impedance changes, etc.). Therefore, if model architectures and data processing are tailored for bio-signal applications and take into consideration signal evolution with time, deep learning can become a solution for more robust motor intention decoding.
topic: The concept and applications of nonbiomimetic EMG decoders relying on user learning of inverse mappings for prosthetic control.
question: How does the nonbiomimetic EMG decoding approach that relies on user learning of inverse mappings fundamentally differ from biomimetic decoding methods in prosthetic hand control, and what are the primary implications of this difference for the user's motor learning and control dexterity?

choices.A: It uses direct mapping of EMG signals to natural muscle activation patterns, requiring minimal user adaptation but limiting dexterity due to predefined biological constraints.
choices.B: It provides an arbitrary abstract control space requiring the user to learn new EMG-to-control mappings, enabling potentially higher dexterity but demanding substantial motor learning and cognitive effort.
choices.C: It classifies discrete hand gestures from EMG features without continuous control, simplifying training but reducing simultaneous multi-DOF control capability.

This approach can offer greater dexterity and flexibility but requires the user to undergo significant motor learning to master the inverse mapping, increasing cognitive demand.

## 3.2. Perspectives
The challenges for future interfaces that can provide the necessary read/write bandwidth to use RPHs in a natural fashion are immense. We argue that the motor and sensory domains raise different problems. Indeed, the stimulation being close to the target is mandatory with current technologies, and therefore the best solutions are the most invasive ones. In the motor domain, it is possible to decompose the signal if we have enough sources (even noninvasive sources, as with sEMG). As shown in Section 4, machine learning techniques can help infer information from noninvasive interfaces.

On the sensory level, the currently implantable electrodes are the most promising solution. However, the main advancement so far has been for the tactile modality, while the use of other modalities for proprioception has been obtained via a nonhomologous approach based on intraneural stimulation combined with the delivery of homologous tactile feedback via indirectly targeted intraneural electrical stimulation (64).

Temperature sensation is another limit. T emperature is mediated through A δ fibers (for cold) and C fibers (for warmth). Given the very small size of these fibers (C fibers are 20-100 times smaller than A β fibers), it is not possible to target them using existing state-of-the-art electrodes (42). Future electrodes with even higher levels of selectivity might be able to target A δ and C fibers. Sensory remapping (65) can be another viable solution to simulate temperature feedback on a different part of the body using a temperature display.
topic: The concept and practical considerations of sensory remapping as a method to simulate temperature feedback in neuroprosthetic applications.
question: Why is sensory remapping considered a viable strategy to simulate temperature feedback in neuroprosthetic applications despite the existence of implantable electrodes, and what neurophysiological constraints underlie this necessity?

choices.A: Because implantable electrodes can selectively stimulate Aβ fibers but cannot target the much smaller Aδ and C fibers responsible for temperature sensation, making direct temperature feedback unfeasible; sensory remapping circumvents this by delivering temperature information via alternative body sites.
choices.B: Because temperature sensations are mediated exclusively by large myelinated fibers easily targeted by current electrodes, but sensory remapping is preferred to avoid invasive procedures.
choices.C: Because current electrodes can target temperature-sensitive fibers directly, but sensory remapping improves the accuracy of temperature perception by combining multiple sensory inputs.
choices.D: Because temperature feedback requires stimulation of motor neurons, which are inaccessible to electrodes, so sensory remapping substitutes motor signals with sensory cues.

explanation: The key neurophysiological constraint is that temperature sensation depends on very small Aδ and C fibers, which are 20 to 100 times smaller than Aβ fibers targeted by existing electrodes, making direct stimulation currently impossible; sensory remapping offers an alternative by simulating temperature feedback on different body parts using temperature displays.

## SKIN MECHANORECEPTORS
The skin has four types of mechanoreceptors, which are sensitive to different stimuli and therefore involved in different sensory functions: Merkel disks (which sense skin indentation, fine touch, and texture perception), Ruffini capsules (which sense skin stretch), Pacinian corpuscles (which sense vibration), and Meissner corpuscles (which sense dynamic deformation and slipperiness). Merkel disks and Ruffini capsules are slow-adapting receptors, meaning that they fire continuously during tactile stimuli, with a firing rate related to the pressure applied in their receptive field. Pacinian corpuscles and Meissner corpuscles are fast-adapting receptors that respond mostly to changes in applied pressure or brief stimuli.

topic: Explore the challenges and strategies involved in implementing agonist/antagonist myoelectric control in robotic prosthetic hands, including its impact on dexterity and user control.
question: What is the primary challenge in implementing agonist/antagonist myoelectric control in robotic prosthetic hands, and how does addressing this challenge affect the prosthesis's dexterity and user control?

choices.A: Achieving independent and simultaneous control of opposing muscle groups is difficult, but successfully doing so enhances dexterity and provides more natural, proportional user control.
choices.B: Minimizing the size of the prosthetic hand components is the main challenge, and overcoming it primarily improves the cosmetic appearance rather than functional dexterity.
choices.C: Ensuring the prosthesis can operate with a single degree of freedom is challenging, and resolving this limits dexterity but simplifies user control.
choices.D: Developing pressure sensors for tactile feedback is the key difficulty, and solving it mainly affects the sensory experience without influencing motor control or dexterity.

explanation: The core difficulty lies in decoding and controlling agonist and antagonist muscle signals independently and simultaneously, which is essential for mimicking natural hand movements. Addressing this challenge allows the prosthesis to achieve finer, more dexterous motions and more intuitive control by the user, closely replicating natural limb function.

## 5.4. Sensory Feedback
In basic myoelectric or body-powered prostheses, feedback is delivered mainly by visually inspecting the movements of the prosthesis and by the physical interaction between the device and the user (126), as with hook prostheses. Clearly, the goal of a modern RPH is to deliver richer information more intuitively.

Sensory feedback strategies are characterized by their precision and the coherence between the evoked sensation and the desired one in terms of timing (synchronicity), position (somatotopy), and modality (i.e., touch, vibration, and temperature). Feedback techniques encode sensor values to stimulation parameters, which in turn are strongly tied to the chosen stimulation interface ( Table 2 ). Here, we focus mainly on electrical interfaces for feedback, but we also briefly discuss the mechanical interfaces.

Noninvasive feedback strategies are attractive approaches since they do not necessitate surgical interventions ( Figure 2 a ). Starting with the Boston Arm, which Mann & Reimers (127) used to demonstrate that position feedback was needed for precise reaching movements, these techniques have improved in both mechanical and electrical interfaces with the user. Indeed, the intact mechanoreceptors in the skin of the arm can be stimulated with small linear (128) or vibrating (129) motors that vary in their driving amplitude and frequency. On the other hand, mechanical stimulation brings an unavoidable delay of approximately 400 ms in the delivery of the sensation (130), and the integration and miniaturization of mechanoreceptors are challenging. The miniaturization of noninvasive feedback approaches is also challenging.
topic: Explore how sensor values from prosthetic devices are encoded into stimulation parameters and the impact of the chosen stimulation interface on feedback quality.
question: How does the choice of stimulation interface in prosthetic sensory feedback systems fundamentally affect the encoding of sensor values into stimulation parameters and the resulting quality of the evoked sensations, particularly in terms of timing and somatotopic coherence?

choices.A: Electrical interfaces enable direct encoding of sensor values into stimulation parameters with minimal delay and high somatotopic specificity, while mechanical interfaces induce longer delays and less precise spatial mapping due to indirect stimulation of skin mechanoreceptors.
choices.B: Mechanical interfaces provide more precise somatotopic feedback and faster timing than electrical interfaces because they stimulate multiple skin mechanoreceptors simultaneously, unlike electrical stimulation which is limited to single nerve fibers.
choices.C: Both electrical and mechanical interfaces encode sensor values identically, but mechanical interfaces are preferred due to their easier miniaturization and integration into prosthetic devices.
choices.D: Electrical interfaces cause unavoidable delays in sensory feedback due to the need for surgical implantation, whereas mechanical interfaces deliver instantaneous stimulation without timing issues.

explanation: Electrical interfaces can directly stimulate nerves or specific receptors, allowing precise control over stimulation parameters that correspond closely with sensor values, thus preserving timing (minimal delay) and somatotopic coherence. Mechanical interfaces stimulate skin mechanoreceptors indirectly, causing inherent delays (~400 ms) and challenges in achieving precise spatial mapping, which degrades feedback quality and synchronicity.

## 7. CONCLUSION
Morethan20years ago,remarkable results by a group of French surgeons for hand transplantation (8) had raised hopes for a future where grafting would be the norm and prosthetics eventually obsolete (176). However, not only has this prediction-unfortunately-not yet come to pass, but also the adoption of new RPH technologies has been slower than expected. As such, RPHs are still a field of active research. Significant efforts have been made to reduce their price and weight, improve their aesthetics and anthropomorphism, increase the robustness and accuracy of their motor intention decoding, and provide natural and accurate somatosensory feedback. We have proposed here an outline of possible iterations of RPHs for the next few years and for 5-10 years in the future.

In our view, there could soon be a broader integration of simple somatosensory feedback using mature implantable techniques, such as cuff electrodes. Motor decoding using machine learning and shared-control algorithms could permit continuous command of single fingers and broader sets of grasps. Ultimately, the next generation of prosthetics could use more advanced soft implantable electrodes, which could enable more sophisticated sensory encoding (proprioception, temperature perception, touch perception, and nociception) and motor decoding using, for example, deep learning techniques. But to reach this goal, the field must tackle significant challenges related to system integration, electronic miniaturization, computational power, surgical procedure, electrode robustness, the robotic hand itself, and the encoding of somatosensory information.
topic: Discuss the current state and future potential of motor intention decoding in robotic prosthetics, including the roles of machine learning and shared-control algorithms.
question: How do machine learning and shared-control algorithms synergistically enhance motor intention decoding in robotic prosthetic hands, and what are the primary multidisciplinary challenges that must be addressed to realize continuous, naturalistic control combined with sophisticated somatosensory feedback?

choices.B: Shared-control algorithms independently decode motor intentions without user input, and machine learning is primarily used for robotic hand mechanics; key challenges are limited to surgical techniques and prosthetic weight reduction.

It also accurately identifies the multidisciplinary challenges detailed in the text, including integration, miniaturization, computational power, surgery, electrode durability, and sophisticated sensory encoding.

## 2.2. Perspectives
While rigid architectures are still the norm, there has been recent interest in the development of flexible systems that inherently permit safe robot-human interaction (29). Instead of using a rigid structure with mechanical joints, the compliant structures in soft designs enable them to bend continuously in any part. Since seminal work by Hirose & Ma (30), there have been several attempts to develop soft underactuated hand prostheses (31) and soft body-powered devices (9). These architectures combine the advantages of simple actuation with the performance of an adaptable hand. Recent studies have proved that soft manipulators could match the performance of rigid systems in many applications (32). Further investigations are necessary to determine whether soft architectures are viable solutions for larger use.

Innovative actuation systems such as McKibben pneumatic muscles, granular jamming (33), and electro-conjugate fluid (34), which are strongly tied to soft robotic devices, are another interesting direction. Soft RPHs have the advantage of exploiting the structure to embed and eventually improve sensorization, safety, and efficiency (e.g., 35). These systems are at the early stage and need massive integration before being deployed in portable devices.

The primary challenge lies in harmonizing these complex components to function seamlessly in portable devices.

## 5. RESTORING SENSORY FEEDBACK
Sensory information plays a critical role in both the exploration of the external environment and in any manipulation task. When an individual interacts with surrounding objects, tactile sensations are used to infer features such as size, compliance, temperature, and texture, while the same sensations are exploited to handle them properly or use them as tools. From this perspective, aiming to restore afferent sensory channels from a hand prosthesis is a critical step in designing a device that ensures two key aspects: dexterous manipulation and embodiment of the prosthetic device.

The design of a sensory feedback system that can successfully deliver information relies on three fundamental blocks working together: ( a ) sensor readings, processed by ( ) an encoding b strategy capable of translating meaningful information to the user, through ( ) an interface. Prec vious sections have described the different available interfaces; here, we present the encoding techniques and sensors relevant to the design of modern hand prostheses ( Table 1 ).

Sensors mounted on a robotic hand should ideally record the whole spectrum of available human sensations, from both external and internal sources. Indeed, sensory information from the human hand covers both interactions with the external world (tactile perception, thermal perception, and nociception, i.e., perception of pain) and internal perception of the positions of the joints and the length and forces exerted by the muscles, together known as proprioception. Table 2 shows examples of sensor placements on RPHs from recent studies.
topic: The impact of sensor placement on robotic prosthetic hands and how it affects the quality and relevance of sensory feedback.
question: How does the strategic placement of sensors on a robotic prosthetic hand fundamentally influence the quality and relevance of sensory feedback, and why is this critical for achieving both dexterous manipulation and embodiment of the prosthesis?

choices.A: Sensor placement determines which sensory modalities (e.g., tactile, thermal, proprioceptive) are captured and their fidelity, thereby directly affecting the accuracy and meaningfulness of feedback necessary for fine motor control and the user’s perception of the prosthesis as part of their body.
choices.B: Sensor placement primarily affects the durability and lifespan of sensors but does not significantly impact the type or quality of sensory feedback delivered to the user.
choices.C: The position of sensors only influences the ease of maintenance and replacement, with no substantial effect on the sensory feedback quality or the functional capabilities of the prosthetic hand.
choices.D: Sensor placement is only important for aesthetic integration of the prosthetic hand and has minimal role in the functional restoration of sensory feedback or embodiment.

explanation: Strategic sensor placement is critical because it ensures that sensors capture the full spectrum of relevant sensations—external (tactile, thermal, nociception) and internal (proprioception)—with high fidelity and contextual relevance. This comprehensive and accurate sensory input is necessary for users to perform dexterous manipulation tasks effectively and to experience embodiment, perceiving the prosthesis as an extension of their own body.

## 5.1. Sensors for Proprioception
Proprioception is not only fundamental for a dexterous hand prosthesis, enabling vision-free manipulation and multitasking, but is also the key to a properly embodied device (64). Usually, kinematic parameters of the robotic hand and (when available) the force exerted are needed to implement low-level control of the actuators, so they are measured with well-established systems, such as rotary encoders or the motor's current draw.


## 5.2. Tactile Sensors
Despite improvements in sensor miniaturization,computational power,and knowledge of the neurophysiology of somatosensation (tactile sensation and proprioception), the capabilities of sensorized RPHs remain far from those of a natural hand. Overcoming this limitation will require satisfying three conditions: The sensors must match the skin's sensing ability, a sufficient number of sensors must be embedded on the surface of the hand, and it must be possible to reliably read information from them. The first condition can be addressed with current technology, as the resolution of existing force and pressure sensors already matches human skin performance (120). However, fulfilling the second and third conditions is another matter, and we need to push the boundaries of circuit integration in order to create an RPH with many sensors and a way to communicate with them.

The classical solution of using general-purpose sensors developed separately from the signal conditioning circuit and the subsequent signal processing has shown its limit. Instead, efforts are being made to optimize these devices with prosthetics in mind. For example, borrowing the concept of morphological computation from robotics (121), sensors can be optimized for specific tasks by tuning the features of their mechanical structures accordingly. Indeed, exploiting the low-pass filtering effect of a compliant material or surfaces with specific structures can increase texture discrimination (61, 115). Another example comes from Kim et al. (122), who measured forces using sensors embedded in a soft substrate.

topic: The influence of compliant materials and surface structures on the tactile sensing capabilities of prosthetic hands.
question: How does the incorporation of compliant materials and specifically structured surfaces in prosthetic hands enhance tactile sensing capabilities beyond what is achievable by electronic sensor resolution alone?

choices.B: They mechanically pre-process tactile inputs via low-pass filtering effects, improving texture discrimination and reducing the burden on electronic signal processing.
choices.C: They increase the number of sensors that can be embedded on the prosthetic surface by physically shrinking sensor size.
choices.D: They enable direct neural stimulation bypassing the need for external sensors, thus improving proprioceptive feedback.

explanation: Compliant materials and structured surfaces function by mechanically filtering and shaping tactile inputs (a form of morphological computation), which enhances texture discrimination and reduces the need for complex electronic signal conditioning; this mechanical pre-processing complements sensor resolution rather than replacing it. topic: Comparative analysis of various prosthetic hand models and their sensory feedback interfaces, highlighting design diversity and evolution.
question: How do variations in sensory feedback interface types and encoding strategies across different prosthetic hand models critically influence the balance between embodiment, tactile discrimination, and reliable sensor integration, and what design trade-offs emerge from these variations?

choices.A: Electrical stimulation interfaces with fixed pulse width and amplitude provide consistent feedback but limit texture discrimination, favoring reliable sensor integration over embodiment.
choices.B: Mechanical stimulation encoding through linear signals optimizes texture discrimination via morphological computation but complicates reliable sensor integration, enhancing embodiment at the cost of signal processing complexity.
choices.C: Neuromorphic encoding of electrical stimulation in newer models offers a dynamic and biomimetic feedback that improves embodiment and tactile discrimination while requiring advanced circuit integration to maintain reliability.
choices.D: Using general-purpose sensors separated from signal processing circuits maximizes sensor density and reliability but sacrifices the naturalness of tactile feedback and embodiment.

explanation: Neuromorphic encoding combines biomimetic dynamic stimulation with advanced circuit integration, enabling prosthetic hands to better mimic natural tactile feedback and enhance embodiment without compromising sensor reliability, reflecting a key evolutionary design trade-off.

## 4.3. Decoding Motor Intention via Implanted Electrodes
Surface electrodes cannot precisely record the signal from deep muscles; to overcome this issue, several groups have focused on iEMG electrodes. This technique is more invasive but allows one to record EMG signals (51) uncorrelated from the underlying musculature and avoids the daily placement of electrodes. iEMG is robust against electrode shift (e.g., socket rotation) and change in skin impedance and sweat. Several studies have demonstrated the performance of simultaneous wrist and hand motions (three DOFs) using six to eight iEMG electrodes; Smith & Hargrove (51) showed that iEMG has better decoding performance than sEMG. High decoding performance is reported in real time (106), and in fully implanted setups, the results are stable for several days (107).

Onthe other hand, Farrell & Weir (52) compared the pattern recognition-based grasp classification performance of iEMG and sEMG on 12 movement classes with eight channels and did not find a statistical difference between electrode types. They concluded that the choice of electrode should be based not on classification accuracy but rather on signal consistency over time and robustness to electrode lift-off. Zia ur Rehman et al. (108) compared a standard linear discriminant analysis with a deep network for grasp classification. They performed a multiday analysis comparing six iEMG and six sEMG electrodes, and their results showed that deep learning had better decoding performance and was more stable over time.

Kamavuako et al. (109) investigated the effect of combining iEMG to target deep muscles with sEMG on myoelectric control. They showed that the combined solution improved offline and real-time control performance compared with sEMG alone.

With 32 iEMG electrodes, Dantas et al. (110) compared different decoding methods for the continuous control of five DOFs corresponding to the flexion and extension of each digit. Using a data set aggregation algorithm, they showed a normalized mean squared error as low as 0.033 with a deep convolutional neural network. They also investigated signal stability for 150 days after training, showing a small degradation during the first month (0.003 normalized mean squared error per day with a convolutional neural network), but that degradation stopped in the next four months.

For transradial amputees, an alternative to using EMG signals to control hand prostheses is decoding from peripheral nerve signals. Different grasp types can be decoded from peripheral nerve signals with high accuracy using different interfaces, both offline and in real time (54, 111113). Implanted peripheral nerve recordings are more invasive than sEMG but are more stable over time. Indeed, donning and doffing the prosthesis does not move these electrodes as much as it does sEMG electrodes. Recently, Cracchiolo et al. (53) decoded up to 11 class states using TIMEs on an amputee subject and showed that the active sites chosen on the first day could also be used in the following sessions, for up to seven days (80% accuracy, compared with 83% by selecting active sites every session). However, this modality is generally used to provide sensory

feedback (64, 114-116). Therefore the development of new approaches to record neural signals during peripheral stimulation [e.g., artifact removal (117)] is necessary.

Vu et al. (39) recently developed a regenerative peripheral nerve interface to increase signal specificity and long-term stability. They implanted transected peripheral nerves into a free muscle graft. After regeneration, revascularization, and reinnervation, the graft becomes a nerve bioamplifier that creates EMG signals. Using chronically implanted iEMG to record from these grafts, they performed five-class decoding in real time with up to 98.2% accuracy with two transradial amputees in a virtual hand environment. They also showed results from a Box and Block T est using an RPH that provided continuous control of two DOFs of thumb motions through their interface combined with a third DOF based on sEMG.
topic: Evaluation of experimental methods and metrics (e.g., normalized mean squared error, classification accuracy) used to assess decoding performance in implanted electrode studies.
question: In evaluating decoding performance of implanted electrode systems for prosthetic control, why is normalized mean squared error (NMSE) considered a more informative metric than classification accuracy when assessing continuous multi-degree-of-freedom (DOF) control, and how does this choice influence the interpretation of signal stability over extended periods?

choices.A: Because NMSE quantifies the continuous prediction error magnitude, it captures subtle deviations in joint angle estimations essential for smooth control, whereas classification accuracy only reflects discrete class membership; thus, using NMSE allows precise tracking of gradual signal degradation over time.
choices.B: Because classification accuracy inherently accounts for continuous signal variations in multi-DOF tasks, NMSE is redundant and primarily used only for offline analysis without real-time implications.
choices.C: Because NMSE is less sensitive to electrode displacement artifacts than classification accuracy, it is preferred for short-term assessments but less informative for long-term stability evaluations.
choices.D: Because classification accuracy provides a more detailed quantification of signal consistency across sessions, it better reflects long-term stability compared to NMSE, which only measures instantaneous error.

explanation: NMSE is a continuous metric that measures the magnitude of prediction errors in continuous control tasks, making it superior to classification accuracy—which only indicates if a discrete class label was correctly identified—for evaluating smooth prosthetic control involving multiple DOFs. This continuous error metric enables detection of subtle, gradual performance degradations over time, crucial for assessing long-term signal stability and robustness in implanted electrode systems.

topic: Methods for achieving multiple degrees of freedom (DOF) control in prosthetic hands using threshold-based sEMG control and cocontraction techniques.
question: In threshold-based sEMG control systems for prosthetic hands, how does cocontraction specifically facilitate the achievement of multiple degrees of freedom (DOF), and what is the primary advantage of this method compared to relying solely on individual muscle activation thresholds?

choices.A: Cocontraction acts as a binary switch to toggle between different grasp modes, allowing a single sEMG channel to control multiple DOFs, thereby overcoming the limitation of few control signals.
choices.B: Cocontraction increases the amplitude of sEMG signals to improve signal-to-noise ratio, enabling finer control over each DOF independently.
choices.C: Cocontraction provides continuous proportional control over finger movements by blending signals from agonist and antagonist muscles.
choices.D: Cocontraction reduces muscle fatigue by alternating activation between muscle groups, thereby sustaining prolonged prosthetic hand use with multiple DOFs.

explanation: Cocontraction in threshold-based sEMG control is used as a deliberate simultaneous activation of antagonistic muscles to trigger a mode-switching event, effectively toggling the prosthesis between different grasp configurations or control modes. This allows a limited number of sEMG channels to command multiple DOFs by switching the control context, overcoming the constraint of having only a few independent muscle signals. Unlike simply increasing signal amplitude or providing proportional control, cocontraction serves as a discrete switch, enabling more complex control schemes without additional sensors.

The cosmetic solution is often used for the most distal amputations (e.g., fingers) but is not adapted for patients with a transradial amputation given the dramatic loss of functionality. Bodypowered mechanical hooks, mainly with one-DOF control, are popular solutions thanks to their the partial amputation of the arm below the elbow, at some point along the radial bone

low price, light weight, and easy maintenance. This type of prosthesis is also well suited for highintensity work due to the control robustness. Also, because the subject must move their shoulder to open and close the hook, these systems have inherent proprioception feedback (9). However, one of the major limitations of the hook solution is the low level of dexterity and nonanthropomorphic appearance. Body-powered hands have solved the anthropomorphic aspect while keeping the robustness of body-powered solutions (10). For example, Baril et al. (11) developed a programmable body-powered hand that can perform different grasp types using a mechanical selector that blocks the closing of one or more fingers. Nevertheless, this solution has its drawback as well: Because of their low mechanical efficiency, body-powered prostheses require large amounts of energy (from 33 N for a hook to 131 N for a hand) to produce a relatively low pinch force (15 N) (12). This could explain their high rejection rate by patients, which ranges between 16% and 66% depending on the survey and time period (13).

Here, we concentrate on RPHs because they potentially offer the most versatile, natural, and power-efficient replacement for amputated hands and could become the default solution for patients. We investigate the challenges in existing RPHs, considering both commercially available solutions ( Supplemental Table 1 ) and those in the research phase ( Supplemental Table 2 ).

Mimicking the biomechanics of a hand is not easy. Early prototypes (14) succeeded in designing fingers with skeleton-like structures, but biomimetic actuation was only recently properly implemented using muscle-like actuators (15). The challenge for RPH developers is to embed actuators, sensors, and electronic components into a prosthesis with the same size and weight as the replaced hand (14, 16, 17). Major system integration and miniaturization are necessary before these systems can be used by amputee patients.

Instead, underactuation is a widespread approach to simplify the mechanics while keeping reasonable dexterity. An underactuated system is one where the number of degrees of actuation (DOAs) is smaller than the number of DOFs (see DOA/DOF < 1 in Supplemental Tables 1 and 2 ). The passive (nonactuated) DOFs are exploited to adapt to the surface in contact, as suggested by the concept of morphological computation (18), and to enable a self-adjusting grip without the need to control each articulation. These systems reduce the number of motors needed in the RPH and therefore its complexity, weight, and price.
topic: Reflect on how current research prototypes of robotic prosthetic hands might evolve to become the default solution for transradial amputees.
question: Considering the challenges of mimicking natural hand biomechanics and the constraints on size, weight, and power efficiency, how does the underactuation approach in robotic prosthetic hands reconcile the trade-off between dexterity and mechanical complexity to potentially make these prostheses the default solution for transradial amputees?

choices.A: By employing a one-to-one mapping of actuators to each degree of freedom, maximizing independent finger control despite increased weight and complexity.
choices.B: By reducing the number of actuators below the number of degrees of freedom, allowing passive adaptation of fingers through morphological computation to maintain dexterity with fewer motors.
choices.C: By completely eliminating actuators and relying on mechanical springs to mimic muscle function, thus minimizing complexity at the expense of limited control.
choices.D: By increasing actuator count and using complex control algorithms to independently control every joint, prioritizing dexterity over weight and cost.

explanation: The underactuation approach reduces the number of actuators relative to the degrees of freedom (DOA < DOF), exploiting passive finger movements and morphological computation to adapt grip surfaces without controlling every joint independently. This strategy balances maintaining reasonable dexterity with reducing mechanical complexity, weight, and cost, addressing key challenges for making robotic prosthetic hands viable default solutions.

## 4.2. Shared Control to Help Motor Decoding
The ultimate goal of RPH control is to be as close as possible to controlling a natural hand. Therefore, an ideal control needs to be intuitive and continuous over individual fingers and wrist movements. Increasing the number of DOFs and developing proportional control will increase dexterity for prosthesis users but will inevitably reduce the overall robustness of the decoder. Since reliability is one of the main factors for upper-limb prosthesis users (102), this is a significant issue for the commercialization of more dexterous control schemes.

One possible solution to improve decoding robustness is to add robotic automation of some portion of the motor command. Shared-control strategies between a subject and a smart robotic hand have been reported for automated preshaping and grasping (103), grip force adjustment

(104), slip detection, and hand closing (105). In the context of single-finger proportional control, Zhuang et al. (79) proposed a shared-control strategy to increase grasp robustness (avoiding accidental drops), by maximizing the number of contacts between the RPH and an object while allowing the user to maintain full autonomy over decisions about grasping and releasing, grasp preshaping, and non-grasp-related motions. These strategies allow both freedom during singlefinger control and robustness during a grasp event (79) and can perform more dexterous movements that cannot be decoded based on EMG alone. However, they necessitate many DOAs (e.g., active control of each phalanx to reposition the fingers around an object), which is still a significant challenge in terms of motor miniaturization, power consumption, and cost.
topic: The trade-offs between increasing degrees of freedom for dexterity and the resulting decrease in motor decoder robustness in upper-limb prosthetic hands.
question: How does increasing the degrees of freedom in upper-limb prosthetic hand control fundamentally affect motor decoder robustness, and why do shared-control strategies present a viable solution despite introducing challenges in miniaturization and power consumption?

choices.A: Increasing degrees of freedom enhances motor decoder robustness by simplifying EMG signal patterns; shared-control strategies automate all movements, eliminating the need for user input and reducing miniaturization challenges.
choices.B: Increasing degrees of freedom decreases motor decoder robustness by complicating EMG signal interpretation; shared-control strategies mitigate this by automating portions of the motor command, maintaining user autonomy while improving reliability, though this increases requirements for miniaturization and power.
choices.C: Increasing degrees of freedom has no significant effect on motor decoder robustness; shared-control strategies primarily address cost reduction rather than control reliability or miniaturization.
choices.D: Increasing degrees of freedom improves motor decoder robustness by allowing proportional control of individual fingers; shared-control strategies reduce the number of degrees of actuation needed, simplifying prosthetic design and power consumption.

explanation: Increasing degrees of freedom complicates decoding EMG signals, reducing robustness because more complex signals are harder to interpret reliably. Shared-control strategies complement user input by automating parts of the hand movements, thereby improving grasp reliability without sacrificing user autonomy, but this requires many degrees of actuation, leading to challenges in miniaturization, power, and cost.

topic: The impact of intraneural and peripheral nerve stimulation sensory feedback on improving task performance, embodiment, and phantom limb pain in upper limb amputees.
question: Considering the mechanisms and outcomes of intraneural and peripheral nerve stimulation for sensory feedback in upper limb amputees, which of the following best explains why intraneural stimulation may provide superior prosthesis embodiment and phantom limb pain relief compared to peripheral nerve stimulation?

choices.A: Intraneural stimulation directly activates afferent fibers within the nerve fascicles, allowing more selective and naturalistic sensory feedback integration, which enhances embodiment and modulates maladaptive cortical reorganization linked to phantom pain.
choices.B: Peripheral nerve stimulation provides more diffuse sensory input that broadly activates surrounding tissues, resulting in less precise feedback and reduced efficacy in embodiment or pain modulation.
choices.C: Intraneural stimulation bypasses the central nervous system, thereby reducing cognitive workload during prosthesis control and improving functional task performance.
choices.D: Peripheral nerve stimulation induces stronger motor responses that interfere with sensory feedback, diminishing the potential for phantom limb pain reduction and embodiment.

explanation: Intraneural stimulation targets specific nerve fascicles, enabling selective activation of sensory afferents that closely mimic natural sensory signals, facilitating better multisensory integration and embodiment of the prosthesis, and effectively reducing phantom limb pain by counteracting maladaptive cortical changes. Peripheral nerve stimulation, while useful, is less selective, leading to less precise feedback and weaker embodiment and pain relief effects.

Examples of available assessment tools. ( a ) The standardized test equipment for the Box and Block T est includes a box with two compartments separated by a barrier and 150 2.5-cm colored blocks. The subject is asked to transfer as many blocks as possible from one compartment to the other in one minute. Panel adapted with permission from Accsim Instrumentos. ( ) The Clothespin Relocation b Test measures hand function (reaching, grasping, and wrist rotation). The measurement consists of the time it takes for the subject to move three clothespins from a horizontal to a vertical bar and then back (see, e.g., 184). Panel adapted with permission from Reference 184. ( ) The Action Research Arm T est standard box is commercially available and contains different objects to assess grasp, grip pinch, c and gross movement functions. Panel reproduced with permission from Rehab Solutions. ( d ) The Virtual Egg T est is a variation of the Box and Block T est where blocks are replaced by breakable objects. In this example, the plastic cubes have a magnetic fuse that breaks if the grasping force exceeds a certain threshold. Panel adapted with permission from Reference 129. ( ) An audio-tactile interaction task e has been used to measure the brain representation of the peripersonal space (the brain's presentation of the space immediately around the body) (175). The test consists of a looming sound (perceived as coming from far away and moving toward the amputated hand) and a vibrator placed on the subject's stump that is triggered when the sound is perceived to be at different distances from the subject (D1 to D5). The position where the presence of the sound facilitates the perception of the vibrator (reaction time) is used as a proxy for the peripersonal space limit ( dashed line ).

These evaluations are used in rehabilitation and have been clinically validated ( Table 3 ). Most of them were developed for neurological impairments (such as a stroke), multiple sclerosis, or spinal cord injuries and have been adapted for the evaluation of RPHs. While these wellestablished evaluations are essential, detailed investigation of RPHs-mainly when integrating sensory feedback capabilities-implies specific challenges that have been addressed in a series of tests introduced in recent years. These tests, although not yet clinically validated, are, in our opinion, of great interest.

The Grasping Relative Index of Performance measures the ability to control the desired force during grasping (139) independently from the control and feedback modalities. This measurement is based on the well-known Fitts' law, which states that the difficulty of a reaching task is given by the log of the ratio between the distance to the target and its size; in other words, the farther away and smaller a target is, the harder it is to reach it. Thumser et al. (162) argued that grasping is similar to pointing with the thumb and finger toward selected positions and defined the index of difficulty for grasping as the ratio of the object's weight to its hardness (where grasping a fragile object is analogous to reaching a small target). Other assessments have been proposed to estimate object stiffness (139) and size discrimination (6); Risso et al. (163) investigated the contribution of vision, tactile feedback via intraneural stimulation, and visuo-tactile integration to estimate the size of a handheld object.

The magnetic table task (164) and the Virtual Egg T est (129) ( Figure 3 d ) are variations of the Box and Block T est in which the blocks are replaced by magnetic cubes and breakable objects, respectively. Both have been used to evaluate the efficacy of different sensory encoding strategies (see 136 for the magnetic table task and 62 for the Virtual Egg T est). Finally, Prosthesis Efficiency and Profitability is an ad hoc measurement for prosthetics with sensory feedback to assess searching, reaching, grasping, manipulating, and decision-making during a foraging task (139).

Use of cognitive load during a sensorimotor task can give an indirect evaluation of the intuitiveness of a task: Do patients need to give their full attention to a particular movement, or are they able to perform it as part of a dual task? Subjects might be asked, for example, to perform a task while counting backward, finding words that start with a given letter, or visually following a moving target on a screen (for an example with a Virtual Egg T est, see 63). More direct measurement of the cognitive burden via electroencephalographic event-related potentials during human-machine interactions has also been proposed (165). Here, the subject must perform a specific task (the primary task) while detecting an auditory stimulus (the secondary task), and the amplitude of the event-related potentials in response to the auditory stimulus then indicates the amount of dedicated attention to the secondary and primary tasks. Simply put, a small response to the auditory cue suggests more extensive attention to the primary task (166) and therefore a greater cognitive load.

The prolonged use of prosthetic limbs can reverse some of the effects of post-traumatic maladaptive plasticity, one of the most debilitating of which is phantom limb pain, a condition present in the majority of subjects with amputation (167). Phantom limb pain has a complex etiology that can be elicited by a multitude of factors, including nociceptive (neuroma hyperactivity), neuropathic (cortical reorganization), or psychogenic mechanisms. Numerous studies have shown that the use of prosthetics with sensory feedback significantly reduces phantom limb pain for upperlimb (38, 112, 114) and lower-limb (166) amputees. T ypical measurements of pain are the McGill Pain Questionnaire (168), the Neuropathic Pain Symptom Inventory (169), and the Visual Analog Pain intensity scale, but it can also be measured with the DASH assessment (146) and the physical domain of the WHOQOL test.

Longitudinal experiments with amputee patients have demonstrated changes in body schema representation and embodiment of the prosthetic when tactile (62, 170) or proprioceptive (171) feedback is provided to the subject. A questionnaire-based measurement inspired by the rubber hand illusion (172) is often used. T ools for psychometrical measurement of the embodiment include a visuo-tactile integration task (173) and a cross-modal congruency task (174). A similar protocol using audio-tactile stimuli (175) revealed changes of the peripersonal space around the stump following prolonged use of a prosthetic limb ( Figure 3 e ). In the same study, the authors used a tactile distance perception task in subjects' healthy and amputated arms to measure the perceived length of the remaining part of the upper limb and the homologous region of the healthy limb.

Etiology: the cause, set of causes, or manner of causation of a disease or condition

There is no single measurement that assesses all aspects of the use of an RPH. T o evaluate the validity of novel technology, the experimenter should consider the multifaceted aspects of the impairment and subjects' biopsychosocial welfare, which is possible only via a series of tools, as presented in this section. In the case of prosthetics with sensory feedback, there is a lack of validated and well-established measurements, but several research groups are working to define adapted measurements, which might become the new norm in the future.
topic: Interpretation and application of the Prosthesis Efficiency and Profitability metric during complex tasks involving searching, reaching, grasping, manipulating, and decision-making.
question: How does the Prosthesis Efficiency and Profitability metric uniquely capture the integration of sensory feedback during complex prosthetic tasks compared to traditional assessments like the Box and Block Test, and what are the implications of this for evaluating the intuitiveness and functional embodiment of advanced prosthetic limbs?

choices.A: It measures only the speed of block transfer without considering sensory feedback, similar to traditional tests, thus providing limited insight into intuitiveness or embodiment.
choices.B: It assesses multi-dimensional tasks including searching, reaching, grasping, manipulating, and decision-making, thereby directly evaluating sensory feedback integration and cognitive load, which traditional tests do not address.
choices.C: It focuses solely on the mechanical durability of the prosthesis under repetitive stress, ignoring sensory feedback and user cognitive engagement.
choices.D: It evaluates phantom limb pain reduction exclusively through subjective questionnaires, without objective measurement of task performance or sensory integration.

explanation: The Prosthesis Efficiency and Profitability metric is designed to evaluate complex, multi-step tasks involving sensorimotor and cognitive functions, explicitly including sensory feedback integration during foraging-like tasks. This contrasts with traditional tests like the Box and Block Test, which focus primarily on speed and gross motor function without assessing sensory feedback or cognitive aspects. Therefore, this metric provides a more holistic measure of prosthetic intuitiveness and embodiment.

## 2.2. Perspectives
While rigid architectures are still the norm, there has been recent interest in the development of flexible systems that inherently permit safe robot-human interaction (29). Instead of using a rigid structure with mechanical joints, the compliant structures in soft designs enable them to bend continuously in any part. Since seminal work by Hirose & Ma (30), there have been several attempts to develop soft underactuated hand prostheses (31) and soft body-powered devices (9). These architectures combine the advantages of simple actuation with the performance of an adaptable hand. Recent studies have proved that soft manipulators could match the performance of rigid systems in many applications (32). Further investigations are necessary to determine whether soft architectures are viable solutions for larger use.

Innovative actuation systems such as McKibben pneumatic muscles, granular jamming (33), and electro-conjugate fluid (34), which are strongly tied to soft robotic devices, are another interesting direction. Soft RPHs have the advantage of exploiting the structure to embed and eventually improve sensorization, safety, and efficiency (e.g., 35). These systems are at the early stage and need massive integration before being deployed in portable devices.

topic: Analyze the various sensory feedback mechanisms employed in prosthetic hands, their current implementation status, and future directions for biomimetic and multimodal feedback systems.
question: Considering the evolution of sensory feedback mechanisms in prosthetic hands from no feedback to advanced biomimetic and multimodal systems, what are the primary technical and biological challenges that must be overcome to achieve effective temperature feedback and proprioception in future prosthetic devices?

choices.A: Developing soft embedded sensors that can reliably transduce temperature and positional information while integrating with neural interfaces to provide naturalistic, multimodal sensory signals without causing user discomfort or signal interference.
choices.B: Increasing the mechanical rigidity of prosthetic hands to enhance sensor durability and ensure stable, high-fidelity force feedback through traditional body-powered mechanisms.
choices.C: Replacing all current motor decoding methods with purely threshold-based sEMG control to simplify the integration of sensory feedback modalities.
choices.D: Eliminating neuromorphic and biomimetic stimulation approaches in favor of solely vibrotactile feedback to reduce system complexity and power consumption.

explanation: Achieving effective temperature feedback and proprioception requires sensors capable of detecting subtle thermal and positional cues embedded in soft prosthetic materials, coupled with neural interfaces that can convey these signals in a naturalistic, multimodal manner. This integration must avoid discomfort or interference, representing a significant bioengineering challenge. Options B, C, and D either contradict the trend toward soft, biomimetic, multimodal feedback or oversimplify control strategies, thus not addressing these challenges.

Electrical stimulation is usually delivered as train pulses, of which width, amplitude, and frequency can be independently modulated and can be conveyed noninvasively through the skin; this technique is generally known as electrotactile feedback (131). Single electrotactile electrodes can be assembled in bands and arrays (132) for targeting multiple sites at the same time, encoding information in both the position and amplitude of the stimulation. The main drawbacks of electrotactile stimulation are the dependence of sensory thresholds on the stimulation position (131), which forces a calibration after each mounting, and the artifacts induced in EMG readings, which strongly impair its application in closed-loop RPHs.

Electrocutaneous stimulation tries to overcome electrotactile limitations by implanting subdermally thin electrodes. Geng et al. (133) characterized the sensations evoked and highlighted improvements in the detection threshold, the threshold of noticeable differences, and the general pleasantness compared with traditional electrotactile feedback. Electrocutaneous stimulation still has technical issues in real-world implementations, such as interference with EMG readings and variability in stimulation parameters over time (134), which impair long-term applications.

Feedback through neural electrodes is a promising modality that matches how sensory information is transmitted in the nervous system ( Figure 2 b ). These electrodes are implemented at both the cortical (135) and peripheral levels. Here, we focus on techniques targeting the peripheral nervous system.

The three controlled parameters are the frequency, amplitude, and pulse width; the most straightforward approach is proportional modulation according to sensor readings. Studies have shown that this method can be successful even in long-term implants (114, 136-138) and confirmed the improvements brought by sensory feedback through peripheral nervous system interfaces in both performance and embodiment.

Compared with noninvasive approaches, invasive neural stimulation has the advantage of being able to elicit sensations intuitive for the user, as they are delivered through the expected biological route (the peripheral nervous system) for sensory feedback. The focus in this field is currently shifting from basic feedback to evoking complex and natural sensations, feeding high-level features such as texture (61), and in general exploiting the potential of stimulating the nerves directly. Noninvasive feedback strategies are limited in the spatial precision of the evoked sensation in both mechanical and electrical stimulation (60).

The naturalness and information content of the stimulation can be improved by modulating with patterns that go beyond a simple relation with the sensor value. George et al. (139) devised two biomimetic stimulation patterns: one that is proportional to the first derivative of the force and another that is proportional to the aggregated tactile nerve response. Both approaches outperformed standard modulation techniques and were felt to be more informative by the user. Valle et al. (62) started from a model of the response to the touch of human afferent fibers and modulated frequency and amplitude according to a simulated fire rate and fiber recruitment; at the cost of a small reduction in sensitivity, the user reported a consistent increase in the naturalness of the sensation together with an increase in dexterity during functional evaluations. Both of these studies highlighted that the goal is not only to elicit precise sensations but also to focus on naturalness and intuitiveness. Neuromorphic stimulation patterns have also proven to be rich in information not only about tactile contact but also about the sliding speed and texture of an object (115).

Considering the complex surgical procedure and the effort needed to develop a peripheral nervous system interface, techniques based on spinal cord stimulation are promising, as they rely on devices that have already been tested and approved by the US Food and Drug Administration. Chandrasekaran et al. (140) recently demonstrated a sensory neuroprosthesis for amputee subjects with spinal cord stimulation ( Figure 2 c ). The main issue with this approach is the difficulty of eliciting natural sensations; biomimetic stimulation approaches could help address this limitation in the future.
topic: The rationale for and implications of delivering sensory feedback through peripheral neural interfaces versus noninvasive approaches in terms of naturalness, intuitiveness, spatial precision, and embodiment.
question: Why do invasive peripheral neural interfaces elicit more natural and intuitive somatosensory feedback with higher spatial precision and embodiment compared to noninvasive approaches, and how do biomimetic stimulation patterns further enhance these advantages?

choices.A: Because invasive interfaces stimulate the peripheral nerves directly along the biological sensory pathways, allowing precise activation of specific afferent fibers, which noninvasive methods cannot achieve due to skin impedance and diffuse activation; biomimetic patterns mimic natural afferent firing, increasing sensation naturalness and functional integration.
choices.B: Because noninvasive methods can only stimulate muscle fibers indirectly, leading to delayed and less localized feedback, whereas invasive methods stimulate sensory receptors in the skin directly; biomimetic patterns provide stronger stimulation amplitudes that improve perception.
choices.C: Because invasive interfaces bypass the peripheral nervous system and stimulate the central nervous system directly, ensuring immediate sensory perception, unlike noninvasive methods that rely on indirect skin mechanoreceptor activation; biomimetic patterns reduce energy consumption of the implant.
choices.D: Because noninvasive approaches deliver electrical pulses only at fixed frequencies and amplitudes that cannot be modulated, whereas invasive interfaces allow proportional modulation; biomimetic patterns encode sensor data as simple on-off signals that improve user comfort.

explanation: Invasive peripheral neural interfaces stimulate the peripheral nerves directly, respecting the natural biological sensory routes, thus enabling selective activation of afferent fibers with high spatial precision and more intuitive sensations; noninvasive methods are limited by skin impedance and diffuse activation that reduce spatial specificity and naturalness. Biomimetic stimulation patterns emulate natural afferent firing patterns, enhancing the naturalness, intuitiveness, and functional embodiment of the sensations elicited.

## 7. CONCLUSION
Morethan20years ago,remarkable results by a group of French surgeons for hand transplantation (8) had raised hopes for a future where grafting would be the norm and prosthetics eventually obsolete (176). However, not only has this prediction-unfortunately-not yet come to pass, but also the adoption of new RPH technologies has been slower than expected. As such, RPHs are still a field of active research. Significant efforts have been made to reduce their price and weight, improve their aesthetics and anthropomorphism, increase the robustness and accuracy of their motor intention decoding, and provide natural and accurate somatosensory feedback. We have proposed here an outline of possible iterations of RPHs for the next few years and for 5-10 years in the future.

In our view, there could soon be a broader integration of simple somatosensory feedback using mature implantable techniques, such as cuff electrodes. Motor decoding using machine learning and shared-control algorithms could permit continuous command of single fingers and broader sets of grasps. Ultimately, the next generation of prosthetics could use more advanced soft implantable electrodes, which could enable more sophisticated sensory encoding (proprioception, temperature perception, touch perception, and nociception) and motor decoding using, for example, deep learning techniques. But to reach this goal, the field must tackle significant challenges related to system integration, electronic miniaturization, computational power, surgical procedure, electrode robustness, the robotic hand itself, and the encoding of somatosensory information.
topic: Explore the ethical and practical implications of replacing biological hand transplantation with robotic prosthetic solutions in the context of long-term patient outcomes and quality of life.
question: Considering the current technological challenges and future advancements in robotic prosthetic hands (RPHs), what is the most significant ethical and practical implication of replacing biological hand transplantation with RPHs for long-term patient outcomes and quality of life?

choices.A: RPHs eliminate the risks of immunosuppression and graft rejection inherent in transplantation, but their limited sensory feedback currently compromises natural hand function and patient embodiment.
choices.B: Biological hand transplantation offers superior motor control and sensory feedback without significant surgical risks, making it ethically preferable despite the need for lifelong immunosuppression.
choices.C: The use of advanced machine learning in RPHs fully compensates for the lack of biological tissue integration, ensuring equivalent patient quality of life without surgical complexity.
choices.D: The high cost and technological complexity of RPHs make transplantation the more practical solution for most patients, regardless of immunological challenges.

explanation: The key implication is that while RPHs avoid the severe immunological and surgical risks of transplantation, their current sensory and motor integration limitations affect natural function and embodiment, impacting long-term quality of life; future advances may reduce these gaps but the trade-off remains ethically and practically significant.

topic: Long-term stability and home-use feasibility of implanted sensory feedback systems for upper-limb prosthesis users.
question: Considering the demonstrated long-term (>5 years) stability of implanted flat interface nerve electrodes (FINE) and short-term (up to 13 days) home-use electrical stimulation for sensory feedback, which of the following best explains the primary challenge in translating implanted sensory feedback systems into widespread, reliable home-use applications for upper-limb prosthesis users?

choices.A: Ensuring that the sensory feedback encoding via implanted electrodes can robustly convey complex object properties such as shape and stiffness without degradation over extended daily use.
choices.B: Overcoming signal variability caused by external factors such as sweating, arm positioning, and socket rotation that affect implanted electrode performance.
choices.C: Addressing the immunological rejection and surgical complications inherent to long-term implantation of sensory electrodes, which currently limit their clinical viability.
choices.D: Developing fully implanted myoelectric sensors to replace surface electromyography (sEMG) control systems, which are inherently unreliable for grasp classification.

explanation: Although implanted FINE electrodes have shown stability over more than five years, the primary limitation for home-use sensory feedback lies in ensuring that the stimulation protocols can deliver consistent, meaningful sensory information reliably during extended daily use without performance degradation. Signal variability is less problematic for implanted electrodes compared to surface sensors, and immunological rejection is not highlighted as a current barrier for implanted electrodes like FINE. The question focuses on sensory feedback translation, not on replacing sEMG with fully implanted myoelectric sensors.

## Current Solutions and Future Trends for Robotic Prosthetic Hands
Vincent Mendez, 1, ∗ Francesco Iberite, 2, ∗ Solaiman Shokur, 1,† and Silvestro Micera 1,2,†

1 Center for Neuroprosthetics and Institute of Bioengineering, École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne, 1202 Genève, Switzerland; email: silvestro.micera@epfl.ch

2 BioRobotics Institute and Department of Excellence in Robotics and AI, Scuola Superiore Sant'Anna, 56127 Pisa, Italy


## Keywords
hand, prosthesis, neuroprostheses, sensory feedback, electromyography, EMG


## Abstract
The desire for functional replacement of a missing hand is an ancient one. Historically, humans have replaced a missing limb with a prosthesis for cosmetic, vocational, or personal autonomy reasons. The hand is a powerful tool, and its loss causes severe physical and often mental debilitation. Technological advancements have allowed the development of increasingly effective artificial hands, which can improve the quality of life of people who suffered a hand amputation. Here, we review the state of the art of robotic prosthetic hands (RPHs), with particular attention to the potential and current limits of their main building blocks: the hand itself, approaches to decoding voluntary commands and controlling the hand, and systems and methods for providing sensory feedback to the user. We also briefly describe existing approaches to characterizing the performance of subjects using RPHs for grasping tasks and provide perspectives on the future of different components and the overall field of RPH development.
topic: The importance of combining voluntary control and sensory feedback to achieve more natural and effective prosthetic hand function.
question: Why is the integration of voluntary motor command decoding and sensory feedback crucial for achieving natural and effective control in robotic prosthetic hands, and what are the primary challenges in implementing this integration in current neuroprosthetic systems?

choices.A: Because voluntary motor commands alone provide sufficient control, sensory feedback is redundant; the main challenge is miniaturizing hardware.
choices.B: Because sensory feedback compensates for the absence of natural proprioception and touch, enabling adaptive and precise manipulation; challenges include accurate decoding of motor intent and delivering intuitive, timely sensory signals.
choices.C: Because sensory feedback replaces the need for voluntary control by automating hand movements; the main challenge is developing fully autonomous prosthetics.
choices.D: Because voluntary control and sensory feedback operate independently without interaction; the main challenge is integrating the prosthetic hand mechanically with the residual limb.

explanation: The integration is critical because voluntary motor commands provide intent but lack the natural sensory signals (proprioception and tactile feedback) necessary for adaptive, precise control; without this feedback, users rely on visual cues alone, reducing effectiveness and naturalness. The primary challenges include accurately decoding the user’s motor intentions from noisy biological signals and delivering sensory feedback that is intuitive, timely, and perceived as natural by the user.

topic: The challenges and solutions in decoding motor intent from surface and intramuscular electromyography (EMG) signals for multifunction prosthetic hand control.
question: In the context of multifunction prosthetic hand control, what are the primary trade-offs between using surface electromyography (sEMG) and intramuscular electromyography (iEMG) for decoding motor intent, particularly regarding signal specificity, long-term stability, invasiveness, and control performance?

choices.A: sEMG offers higher signal specificity and long-term stability but is invasive and less robust to electrode displacement, whereas iEMG is non-invasive, less specific, and suffers from poor control performance.
choices.B: sEMG is non-invasive and easier to apply but suffers from lower signal specificity and susceptibility to electrode displacement, while iEMG provides higher signal specificity and more stable control at the cost of invasiveness and potential long-term electrode degradation.
choices.C: Both sEMG and iEMG provide comparable signal specificity and stability, but iEMG is preferred because it is non-invasive and easier to implement in clinical settings.
choices.D: iEMG signals are always superior to sEMG in every aspect including invasiveness, signal quality, and user comfort, making sEMG obsolete for multifunction prosthetic hand control.

explanation: Surface EMG is non-invasive and easier to apply but has lower signal specificity and is sensitive to electrode displacement and skin conditions, leading to less stable control. Intramuscular EMG provides more specific and stable signals closer to the motor units, improving decoding accuracy and control performance, but requires invasive implantation with risks of long-term electrode degradation and surgical complications.
