## 4.1. Decoding Algorithms
The clinical standard for RPH control is based on the use of two sEMG channels, with the electrodes placed superficially on antagonist muscles. The envelope of the signal is extracted so that the user can control the closing and opening of the RPH by modulating the amplitude of their muscle contraction. When the amplitude exceeds a certain threshold, the RPH will move depending on which muscle was activated. Companies are offering more DOFs, using cocontraction to

cycle through different types of grasps (e.g., Ottobock's Michelangelo hand). However, this type of control is highly nonintuitive and gives only low dexterity to the user. An alternative to this direct control approach is based on pattern recognition methods, extracting hand-crafted features to characterize the signal in a discriminative way (e.g., the signal root mean square, wavelength, and zero crossing) and classify the type of grasp intended by the user. This solution has become robust enough to reach the market (the Coapt system and Ottobock's Myo Plus). Using 2-12 bipolar sEMG electrodes makes it possible to obtain good classification rates for different kinds of grasps, with 90-95% accuracy for 4-12 classes and up to 75% for 50 classes (68-72).

Using a similar electrode disposition and classification method, other groups showed the possibility of decoding single-finger movement using the classification of flexion or extension (73, 74). Recently, Bhagwat & Mukherji (75) showed single- and multifinger classification of 15 different movements with 99.79% accuracy. Researchers are also working on proportional control instead of classification, which makes it possible to decode several DOFs (e.g., wrist and finger movements) simultaneously and proportionally (76, 77). This type of control offers continuous position control. Several studies have also shown that single-finger proportional control is feasible, with good results (78, 79).

As an alternative, nonbiomimetic EMG decoders have been developed that rely on the subject learning inverse maps to relate motor outputs to arbitrary control variables (80). Using an abstract decoding cursor control space, subjects can learn to modulate their EMG activity to reach different targets arranged in a center-out task in order to trigger various grasping movements (81). Dyson et al. (82) recently validated these results on amputee participants; they showed that after training, the difficulty of the tasks could be increased, improving the possibilities for robotic hand control.

With only a few electrodes placed on muscles of interest, the accurate positioning of the electrodes requires anatomical knowledge; indeed, the type of amputation (congenital or traumatic), the surgical procedure, and the time since amputation (83) could influence the muscle anatomy and make the placement of the electrode tedious and specific to individual subjects. Moreover, a small shift in electrode placement can disrupt the pattern recognition algorithm (84). T o tackle these issues, several authors have proposed HD-sEMG, which consists of a grid of closely spaced electrodes, as an alternative solution. The large number of electrodes allows information to be recorded from a large part of the subject's forearm.

HD-sEMG signals offer high spatial resolution, and recorded signals can be interpreted as spatial images of EMG activity. Using this image representation of EMG data, HD-sEMG is robust to small electrode shifts (85). Boschmann & Platzner (85) used a structural similarity index, borrowed from the computer vision field, on HD-sEMG images combined with a simple one-against-one nearest-neighbor classifier to decode wrist and hand motions. Similarly, Stango et al. (86) used a variogram of images (a measure of the degree of spatial correlation, used mainly in geostatistics) to classify wrist movements. Both groups showed that their methods, which use spatial information from the images, performed better or similarly to the classic feature extraction approach. Moreover, their strategies improved the robustness to electrode shift and electrode number. The use of several spatially close electrodes makes it possible to decompose the EMG signal into its constituent motor unit action potential (50, 87). Kapelner et al. (88) investigated this approach, decomposing EMG signals to extract motor unit activity from forearm muscles during wrist motions. Recently, Dai & Hu (89) showed that an approach consisting of finger joint angle estimation, combining classification for finger selection with EMG decomposition into motor unit activity, outperforms a standard amplitude-based approach.

We observe a paradigm shift from feature engineering to feature learning using raw data as input for deep neural networks. Studies have shown that combining this deep learning approach with HD-sEMG offers better performance than hand-crafted features in both grasp classification

(90) and simultaneous single-finger and wrist movement classification (91). Deep learning has also shown good results with a smaller number of electrodes for grasp classification (72) and regression of arm or wrist motions (92, 93).

This approach permits both high dexterity and robustness, with unprecedented performance. However,one of the major difficulties of the deep learning approach is that it requires an extensive data set for training. For example, the deep learning used for the ImageNet challenge in 2012 used 1.2 million images for training on 1,000 categories (94). In the context of hand gesture recognition, generating tens of thousands of examples for a subject is not a viable option.

A possible solution could use domain adaptation [often called transfer learning in the EMG literature (95, 96)], by leveraging data acquired from several subjects to enhance and accelerate training for a new user. Indeed, the aim is to use information from a database of several source domains and adapt it to a target domain (the end user) with a small number of samples. Authors generally apply deep domain adaptation (domain adaptation combined with deep learning) by pretraining a deep neural network and fine-tuning it with a few repetitions of movements by a target subject. The main idea is that gathering the recordings of several participants can meet the necessary conditions to learn a general mapping of all users' sEMG signals.

Using this idea, Côté-Allard et al. (97) showed that their deep model was able to learn the features and significantly enhance the performance of deep networks on out-of-sample gestures. Using HD-sEMG and deep learning, Du et al. (98) also showed an unsupervised deep domain adaptation method that incrementally learns from data during a new session without explicit calibration of gestures. Consequently, deep learning offers a particularly attractive context from which to develop deep domain adaptation algorithms to leverage interuser data. This approach can increase decoding performance, improve robustness to electrode shift, and reduce the number of repetitions needed during training (99).

As seen in this section, the search for new EMG decoding algorithms that go beyond thresholdbased detection is an active field of research. Phinyomark & Scheme (100) and Khamparia & Singh (101) have reviewed recent research in EMG pattern recognition methods.

Machine learning in the field of computer vision and object recognition has shown outstanding results using deep learning and is already used commercially by many companies. Some deep learning algorithms based on a pretrained network are now usable without any fine-tuning (e.g., self-driving cars). However, bio-signals are intrinsically different from images and need adaptation. More important, the amount of labeled EMG data available to effectively train deep networks might not be sufficient to capture the evolution of the signal over time (electrode displacement, skin impedance changes, etc.). Therefore, if model architectures and data processing are tailored for bio-signal applications and take into consideration signal evolution with time, deep learning can become a solution for more robust motor intention decoding.
topic: The benefits and challenges of applying deep neural networks to sEMG decoding, including data requirements and generalization to new users.
question: Considering the application of deep neural networks to high-density sEMG decoding for prosthetic hand control, which of the following best explains why domain adaptation (transfer learning) is essential despite the superior performance of deep learning models trained on large datasets?

choices.A: Because deep neural networks inherently lack the ability to model complex spatial patterns in sEMG signals without transfer learning.
choices.B: Because the physiological variability across users and electrode placement differences cause significant intersubject signal heterogeneity that large datasets alone cannot fully address.
choices.C: Because deep learning models require manual feature engineering to generalize across users, which domain adaptation automates.
choices.D: Because domain adaptation allows deep learning models to function without any labeled data from the target user, eliminating training time entirely.

explanation: Although deep learning models achieve high accuracy with large datasets, sEMG signals vary greatly between users due to physiological differences and electrode placement variability, limiting direct model generalization. Domain adaptation leverages data from multiple subjects to fine-tune the model with minimal target user data, improving robustness and reducing calibration needs.

## 5.5. Perspectives
We believe that sensorization will play a significant role in the next generation of RPHs. Here, we discuss three main directions influenced by sensorization: embedded sensorization, improved stimulation strategies, and new computational architectures.

5.5.1. Embedded sensorization. Sensorized hands are not yet prevalent in the literature but are starting to draw interest, especially with the improvement of interfaces for bidirectional prostheses (for a list of RPHs with sensorized fingertips, see Supplemental Tables 1 and 2 ). As a recent example, Controzzi et al. (141) developed the Mia hand (Prensilia, Italy), which is integrated with sensors that can measure normal and tangential forces at the fingertips. Sensorization of RPHs is a design requirement that should be considered as important as other functional requirements for hand prostheses, such as weight or dexterity. T o improve RPH performance and sensor integration, next-generation RPHs should then be designed with their sensorization in mind. Information about hand state (joint position, forces, and touch) can also be beneficial to increase the dexterity of such hands, enabling automatic adjustments such as catching slipping objects (e.g., the bebionic3 hand) and shared-control strategies (see Section 4).

5.5.2. Improved stimulation strategies. Biomimicry is one of the strongest trends in nerve stimulation strategies, as it promises to deliver biologically plausible stimulation patterns to evoke more natural sensations. Biomimetic approaches rely on bio-inspired models to compute the stimulation patterns, so new iterations of these models, based on the current experience in stimulation and neural recording, are needed to improve the quality of elicited sensations.

These model-based approaches permit simpler modulation strategies that increase the naturalness of sensations. T an et al. (38), for example, proved that a sinusoidal modulation of the pulse width improves the naturalness of the sensation. Formento et al. (142) instead designed a strategy to activate asynchronously stimulated fibers, mimicking healthy neural activity; in their work, they replaced classical biphasic stimulation with a high-frequency burst of pulses that slowly increased in amplitude, and confirmed their hypothesis in ex vivo experiments. Stimulation patterns that try to overcome the physical limits of present neural interfaces (as in 142) while paving the way for more natural evoked sensations also suggest the requirements for the future generation of neural interfaces and stimulators for sensory feedback: increase reaching without losing discrimination.

5.5.3. New computational architectures. Neuromorphic architectures have the potential to represent a paradigm shift in the design of the control systems for bidirectional hand prostheses, going toward distributed systems and edge computing. Both sensor acquisition and stimulation can benefit from these trends because they lead to more reliable systems that scale well with the increase of sensors and stimulation active sites. If the next generation of neuromorphic hardware promotes portability and lower power consumption, it could lead to broader implementation and adoption of neuromorphic systems in bidirectional hand prostheses.

Many RPHs rely on advanced encoding and decoding algorithms implemented with neural networks (62), which are more computationally demanding than traditional approaches. It is interesting that even deep learning networks can be translated into spiking neural networks (143), possibly enabling full neuromorphic hardware encoding and decoding in future prostheses.
topic: The implications of sensor data (joint position, forces, touch) for automatic adjustment mechanisms and shared control strategies in prosthetic hands.
question: How do the integration of joint position, force, and touch sensor data collectively enable automatic adjustment mechanisms and shared control strategies in robotic prosthetic hands, and what are the implications of this sensor fusion for the design of future computational architectures in bidirectional prostheses?

choices.A: By providing real-time feedback on hand state that allows automatic reactive behaviors and user-assistive control, sensor fusion demands computational architectures that support low-latency distributed processing and scalability to handle complex multimodal data.
choices.B: By replacing the need for user input entirely, sensor data enable fully autonomous prosthetic hand operation, which simplifies computational requirements by eliminating the need for neural network decoding.
choices.C: By primarily improving cosmetic appearance through sensor-embedded fingertips, sensor data mainly enhance user satisfaction but have minimal impact on control strategies or computational design.
choices.D: By providing redundant data streams that serve as backups in case of sensor failure, sensor fusion reduces the overall computational load by simplifying control algorithms to basic threshold triggers.

explanation: The combination of joint position, force, and touch sensors provides detailed, real-time information about the prosthetic hand's state, enabling automatic adjustments such as grip modulation to prevent object slip and facilitating shared control where both user intent and sensor feedback contribute to movement. This multimodal sensor fusion increases data complexity, necessitating advanced computational architectures like neuromorphic systems that support distributed, low-power, and scalable processing for encoding and decoding neural signals and sensor inputs.

topic: Neuropathic and phantom limb pain measurement techniques, including the McGill Pain Questionnaire and Neuropathic Pain Symptom Inventory, and their relevance to prosthetic users.
question: How do the McGill Pain Questionnaire and the Neuropathic Pain Symptom Inventory differ in their conceptual frameworks and clinical applications for assessing neuropathic and phantom limb pain in prosthetic users, and why is this distinction significant for optimizing prosthetic sensory feedback interventions?

choices.A: The McGill Pain Questionnaire primarily assesses qualitative sensory and affective pain descriptors to capture the multidimensional pain experience, while the Neuropathic Pain Symptom Inventory focuses on specific neuropathic pain symptoms quantitatively; this distinction is significant because tailoring prosthetic sensory feedback requires precise identification of neuropathic pain characteristics rather than general pain quality.
choices.B: Both the McGill Pain Questionnaire and the Neuropathic Pain Symptom Inventory measure only the intensity of pain, making them interchangeable for prosthetic applications where pain intensity is the sole concern for sensory feedback adjustment.
choices.C: The Neuropathic Pain Symptom Inventory captures emotional and psychological aspects of phantom limb pain, whereas the McGill Pain Questionnaire is limited to physical pain intensity, making the former more useful for prosthetic users with complex pain profiles.
choices.D: The McGill Pain Questionnaire is designed exclusively for phantom limb pain, while the Neuropathic Pain Symptom Inventory is exclusively for musculoskeletal pain, limiting their combined use in prosthetic sensory feedback design.

explanation: The McGill Pain Questionnaire is a multidimensional tool capturing qualitative sensory and affective dimensions of pain, useful for understanding the overall pain experience, whereas the Neuropathic Pain Symptom Inventory quantitatively assesses specific neuropathic pain symptoms; this allows clinicians to identify neuropathic pain features more precisely, which is critical for designing prosthetic sensory feedback systems that target and potentially alleviate neuropathic and phantom limb pain effectively.

## 4.4. Perspectives
Motor decoding for RPHs is progressing in two main directions: Noninvasive approaches have seen advances in decoding algorithms using large data sets and increases in the number of recording points, and implanted electrodes (either muscular or intraneural) have seen improvements that enable better recording stability and more robust decoding. There is currently no consensus on which approach is best for transradial amputee patients, as they each have their own strengths and limitations. The need for daily signal and classification recalibration is a weak point of the classic sEMG approach, which is being addressed by several research groups developing, for example, HD-sEMG.And despite iEMG's promising control performance, which is robust to donning and doffing of the prosthesis, its overall performance gain, when compared with sEMG, may not currently be sufficient to justify an invasive surgery. The same reasoning can be applied to intraneural electrodes.

One can imagine a future where both invasive and noninvasive approaches will continue to progress and will target either patients who prefer a stable decoding setup or those who do not want to undergo surgery and will accept the need to calibrate their prosthesis on a regular basis (118). Another scenario can be a parallel development of invasive technologies for both sensory and motor functions. Indeed, as shown in Section 5, the approach using intraneural implanted electrodes has permitted unprecedented levels of somatosensory restoration; it might, therefore, be reasonable to perform a single surgery to restore both motor and sensory functions. For this reason, motor decoding using the intraneural interface can become a viable solution if these interfaces one day permit both providing sensory feedback and recording discriminative signals for motor decoding in parallel, but online artifact removal remains an important challenge.

Power consumption is another critical issue: RPHs should embed small electronics because the size of the prosthesis limits the space available for batteries, but doing so usually comes at the cost of limited processing resources. Also, the electronics for the HD-sEMG remain cumbersome due to the large number of input channels and should be miniaturized and portable. Moreover, decoding model complexity is also limited by portable processing resources. In practice, an increased number of electrodes is already available in wearable systems (Sessantaquattro, OT Bioelettronica, Italy) and may become available for prostheses in the future.

Finally, low latency is paramount for seamless prosthesis control [ < 300 ms between user intention and real-time decoding (119)]. Among the studies discussed above, only a few performed analyses to show the feasibility of real-time control (without processing resource limitations), and even fewer included embedded electronics that would translate for home use. One possible solution for real-time decoding with complex models is to bypass embedded electronic limitations; this could be achieved by taking advantage of the computational power of cell phones or by relying on cloud computing and the next generations of wireless cellular networks for low-latency communication.
topic: Discuss innovative approaches to overcome processing resource limitations in prosthetic devices, such as leveraging the computational power of smartphones or cloud computing alongside next-generation wireless networks.
question: In the context of overcoming processing resource limitations in robotic prosthetic hands, what are the primary technical trade-offs and challenges involved when leveraging external computational platforms such as smartphones or cloud computing combined with next-generation low-latency wireless networks for real-time motor decoding?

choices.A: The main trade-off is between increased power consumption in the prosthesis and reduced decoding model complexity due to limited embedded processing, with no significant concerns about communication latency or reliability.
choices.B: While external computation offloads processing from the prosthesis, challenges include maintaining sub-300 ms latency for seamless control, ensuring reliable and low-latency wireless communication, managing power consumption for data transmission, and handling potential data privacy and security issues.
choices.C: Using smartphones or cloud computing eliminates all processing and power constraints on the prosthesis, making embedded electronics unnecessary and removing the need for any recalibration or artifact removal.
choices.D: The critical challenge is solely the miniaturization of the electronics within the prosthesis, as external computational resources and wireless networks inherently guarantee flawless real-time control without latency or connectivity issues.

explanation: The correct answer identifies that although offloading computation externally helps overcome embedded processing limits, it introduces significant challenges related to maintaining low latency (<300 ms) critical for real-time control, ensuring reliable wireless connectivity, managing power for communication, and addressing data privacy/security concerns. It reflects a nuanced understanding of the interplay between embedded limitations and external resource use.

low price, light weight, and easy maintenance. This type of prosthesis is also well suited for highintensity work due to the control robustness. Also, because the subject must move their shoulder to open and close the hook, these systems have inherent proprioception feedback (9). However, one of the major limitations of the hook solution is the low level of dexterity and nonanthropomorphic appearance. Body-powered hands have solved the anthropomorphic aspect while keeping the robustness of body-powered solutions (10). For example, Baril et al. (11) developed a programmable body-powered hand that can perform different grasp types using a mechanical selector that blocks the closing of one or more fingers. Nevertheless, this solution has its drawback as well: Because of their low mechanical efficiency, body-powered prostheses require large amounts of energy (from 33 N for a hook to 131 N for a hand) to produce a relatively low pinch force (15 N) (12). This could explain their high rejection rate by patients, which ranges between 16% and 66% depending on the survey and time period (13).

Here, we concentrate on RPHs because they potentially offer the most versatile, natural, and power-efficient replacement for amputated hands and could become the default solution for patients. We investigate the challenges in existing RPHs, considering both commercially available solutions ( Supplemental Table 1 ) and those in the research phase ( Supplemental Table 2 ).

Mimicking the biomechanics of a hand is not easy. Early prototypes (14) succeeded in designing fingers with skeleton-like structures, but biomimetic actuation was only recently properly implemented using muscle-like actuators (15). The challenge for RPH developers is to embed actuators, sensors, and electronic components into a prosthesis with the same size and weight as the replaced hand (14, 16, 17). Major system integration and miniaturization are necessary before these systems can be used by amputee patients.

Instead, underactuation is a widespread approach to simplify the mechanics while keeping reasonable dexterity. An underactuated system is one where the number of degrees of actuation (DOAs) is smaller than the number of DOFs (see DOA/DOF < 1 in Supplemental Tables 1 and 2 ). The passive (nonactuated) DOFs are exploited to adapt to the surface in contact, as suggested by the concept of morphological computation (18), and to enable a self-adjusting grip without the need to control each articulation. These systems reduce the number of motors needed in the RPH and therefore its complexity, weight, and price.
topic: Investigate the reasons behind high patient rejection rates of body-powered prostheses and propose potential design improvements.
question: Considering the high mechanical energy demands and low pinch force output of traditional body-powered prostheses, how does the concept of underactuation combined with morphological computation provide a strategic design improvement to reduce patient rejection rates, and what are the critical biomechanical trade-offs involved?

choices.A: Underactuation reduces the number of actuators, allowing passive finger joints to adaptively conform to objects via morphological computation, thereby lowering control effort and prosthesis weight, but it sacrifices precise individual finger control which may limit fine dexterity.
choices.B: Underactuation increases the number of actuators to enhance finger independence and precise grip, improving dexterity at the cost of increased weight and energy consumption, which may deter patients.
choices.C: Morphological computation eliminates the need for any actuators by relying entirely on passive compliance, which fully restores natural hand function but results in fragile prostheses unsuitable for heavy work.
choices.D: Combining underactuation with morphological computation allows the prosthesis to autonomously generate pinch force without user input, reducing the physical effort but increasing system complexity and power consumption.

explanation: Underactuation strategically reduces actuator count, enabling passive degrees of freedom to adapt grip shapes naturally (morphological computation), which reduces user effort and prosthesis complexity, addressing the mechanical inefficiency causing patient rejection; however, this comes at the cost of losing precise, independent finger control, representing a key biomechanical trade-off in prosthesis design.

## 5.3. Sensory Architectures
Theproblem of handling many sensors at the same time has been addressed successfully in the past by using time-sharing (multiplexing) and space-sharing (matrix arrangement) techniques, minimizing wiring complexity while keeping read latency in an acceptable range. Nevertheless, this approach does not scale well in terms of covering the whole hand with a sensor density comparable to that of the human hand. Additionally, the unavoidable increase in the number of electrical connections makes the system highly susceptible to breakage.

Event-based architectures rely on the concept of send-on-delta (123), where each sensor (comprising an analog front end and an analog-to-digital converter), instead of signaling its value at a constant rate, does so only when the value changes by more than a certain threshold. These architectures have many advantages owing to the sparsity of the data representation. In other words, the communication line does not need to be capable of handling all the sensors simultaneously (as an interaction where all the sensors are triggered in the same moment is unlikely); instead, single sensors are polled at a high rate, which preserves the time structure of the stimulus.

The underlying idea of event-based systems is inspired by how neurons communicate information to each other, sending a train of spikes instead of continuous value. In earlier implementations, data flowed from sensors to the central unit through digital communication lines using well-known protocols such as Universal Asynchronous Transmitter Receiver (UART), Ethernet, and the Controller Area Network (CAN) bus. Some groups have designed communication paradigms by mimicking information encoding by the nerves; using pulses of 20 ns, Bartolozzi et al. (124) showed a 94% improvement in data rate over traditional protocols.

An even more advanced step was made in the work of Lee et al. (125), where the sensors communicate with spikes through the same conductive surface without any flow control, reducing the wires needed to two (data and ground). In this way, at the cost of a decoding stage for sensor value acquisition, the performance of the architecture increased, reaching up to 100,000 sensors sharing the same bus.
topic: Compare the roles and performance characteristics of traditional digital communication protocols (UART, Ethernet, CAN bus) in sensory data transmission.
question: How do traditional digital communication protocols such as UART, Ethernet, and CAN bus fundamentally differ from event-based spike communication architectures in terms of sensor data transmission efficiency and scalability, and what are the primary trade-offs associated with adopting spike-based communication over these conventional protocols?

choices.A: Traditional protocols transmit sensor data continuously or at fixed rates requiring complex wiring and limited scalability, whereas spike-based architectures send data only on significant changes, greatly improving efficiency and scalability but requiring more complex decoding.
choices.B: Traditional protocols use neural-inspired spike trains for data transmission, allowing high sensor density but suffer from high wiring complexity; spike-based architectures use fixed-rate data transmission to simplify decoding at the cost of reduced scalability.
choices.C: Traditional protocols rely on multiplexing multiple sensors on a shared bus with minimal wiring and high scalability, while spike-based architectures require dedicated wiring for each sensor, limiting scalability but simplifying data decoding.
choices.D: Traditional protocols and spike-based architectures have similar transmission efficiencies and scalability, but spike-based methods reduce power consumption by using analog instead of digital signals.

explanation: Traditional digital protocols like UART, Ethernet, and CAN transmit data at fixed rates or continuously, which requires more wiring and limits scalability as sensor density grows; in contrast, spike-based communication sends data only when sensor values change significantly, reducing bandwidth usage and wiring complexity, enabling scalability to hundreds of thousands of sensors on a shared bus, but demands more complex decoding stages.

( a ) Noninvasive strategies include tactors targeting Meissner corpuscles and encoding pressure (4), vibrators that activate Pacinian corpuscle mechanoreceptors (129), and TENS (59), which targets the nerve noninvasively. ( ) Invasive peripheral b nervous system stimulation can be done with cuff electrodes (138) or FINEs (38, 136) that stimulate the nerve from outside the fiber. TIMEs (6, 60, 61, 64, 181) and Utah Slanted Electrode Arrays (182) are more invasive and are inserted through the nerve but stimulate directly from inside the fiber. ( ) Epidural c stimulation of the lateral spinal cord at the cervical level was able to induce tactile sensation in three upperarm amputees (140). Nerve designs in panels a and b adapted with permission from Reference 42; images created with BioRender.com.

Electrical stimulation is usually delivered as train pulses, of which width, amplitude, and frequency can be independently modulated and can be conveyed noninvasively through the skin; this technique is generally known as electrotactile feedback (131). Single electrotactile electrodes can be assembled in bands and arrays (132) for targeting multiple sites at the same time, encoding information in both the position and amplitude of the stimulation. The main drawbacks of electrotactile stimulation are the dependence of sensory thresholds on the stimulation position (131), which forces a calibration after each mounting, and the artifacts induced in EMG readings, which strongly impair its application in closed-loop RPHs.

Electrocutaneous stimulation tries to overcome electrotactile limitations by implanting subdermally thin electrodes. Geng et al. (133) characterized the sensations evoked and highlighted improvements in the detection threshold, the threshold of noticeable differences, and the general pleasantness compared with traditional electrotactile feedback. Electrocutaneous stimulation still has technical issues in real-world implementations, such as interference with EMG readings and variability in stimulation parameters over time (134), which impair long-term applications.

Feedback through neural electrodes is a promising modality that matches how sensory information is transmitted in the nervous system ( Figure 2 b ). These electrodes are implemented at both the cortical (135) and peripheral levels. Here, we focus on techniques targeting the peripheral nervous system.

The three controlled parameters are the frequency, amplitude, and pulse width; the most straightforward approach is proportional modulation according to sensor readings. Studies have shown that this method can be successful even in long-term implants (114, 136-138) and confirmed the improvements brought by sensory feedback through peripheral nervous system interfaces in both performance and embodiment.

Compared with noninvasive approaches, invasive neural stimulation has the advantage of being able to elicit sensations intuitive for the user, as they are delivered through the expected biological route (the peripheral nervous system) for sensory feedback. The focus in this field is currently shifting from basic feedback to evoking complex and natural sensations, feeding high-level features such as texture (61), and in general exploiting the potential of stimulating the nerves directly. Noninvasive feedback strategies are limited in the spatial precision of the evoked sensation in both mechanical and electrical stimulation (60).

The naturalness and information content of the stimulation can be improved by modulating with patterns that go beyond a simple relation with the sensor value. George et al. (139) devised two biomimetic stimulation patterns: one that is proportional to the first derivative of the force and another that is proportional to the aggregated tactile nerve response. Both approaches outperformed standard modulation techniques and were felt to be more informative by the user. Valle et al. (62) started from a model of the response to the touch of human afferent fibers and modulated frequency and amplitude according to a simulated fire rate and fiber recruitment; at the cost of a small reduction in sensitivity, the user reported a consistent increase in the naturalness of the sensation together with an increase in dexterity during functional evaluations. Both of these studies highlighted that the goal is not only to elicit precise sensations but also to focus on naturalness and intuitiveness. Neuromorphic stimulation patterns have also proven to be rich in information not only about tactile contact but also about the sliding speed and texture of an object (115).

Considering the complex surgical procedure and the effort needed to develop a peripheral nervous system interface, techniques based on spinal cord stimulation are promising, as they rely on devices that have already been tested and approved by the US Food and Drug Administration. Chandrasekaran et al. (140) recently demonstrated a sensory neuroprosthesis for amputee subjects with spinal cord stimulation ( Figure 2 c ). The main issue with this approach is the difficulty of eliciting natural sensations; biomimetic stimulation approaches could help address this limitation in the future.
topic: The advantages and limitations of electrotactile and electrocutaneous stimulation methods, especially concerning sensory threshold variability, calibration needs, EMG interference, and long-term stability.
question: Which fundamental limitation of electrotactile stimulation necessitates recalibration after each application, and how does electrocutaneous stimulation attempt to overcome this, despite still facing challenges with EMG interference and long-term parameter variability?

choices.A: Electrotactile stimulation’s dependence on stimulation position causes sensory threshold variability requiring recalibration; electrocutaneous stimulation overcomes this by implanting subdermal electrodes to stabilize thresholds but still suffers from EMG artifacts and parameter drift over time.
choices.B: Electrotactile stimulation’s inability to modulate pulse frequency causes inconsistent sensations requiring recalibration; electrocutaneous stimulation resolves this by fixed-frequency pulses but remains limited by poor spatial resolution.
choices.C: Electrotactile stimulation’s invasive nature causes tissue damage necessitating recalibration; electrocutaneous stimulation uses noninvasive surface electrodes to avoid this but cannot provide natural sensations.
choices.D: Electrotactile stimulation’s high power consumption leads to unstable stimulation intensities needing recalibration; electrocutaneous stimulation reduces power use but introduces latency in feedback.

explanation: Electrotactile stimulation’s sensory thresholds vary with electrode position on the skin, forcing calibration after each mounting. Electrocutaneous stimulation implants subdermal electrodes to achieve more stable detection thresholds and improved pleasantness, but it still encounters EMG interference and variability in stimulation parameters over time, limiting long-term application.

topic: The development and application of event-driven and neuro-inspired sensory encoding for robotic skin and prosthetic tactile sensing.
question: How does event-driven neuro-inspired sensory encoding improve tactile information processing in robotic skin and prosthetic devices compared to traditional continuous sensing methods?

choices.A: By continuously sampling tactile signals at high rates to maximize data accuracy regardless of stimulus changes.
choices.B: By encoding tactile information only upon significant stimulus changes, reducing data redundancy and latency, thereby enabling more efficient and biomimetic sensory feedback.
choices.C: By employing random sampling of tactile data to decrease computational load without regard to stimulus relevance.
choices.D: By converting all tactile signals into fixed-rate digital pulses to standardize data transmission and simplify processing.

explanation: Event-driven neuro-inspired sensory encoding transmits tactile information only when significant changes occur in the stimulus, reducing redundant data and latency. This approach mirrors biological sensory systems, leading to efficient, low-latency, and biomimetic tactile feedback in robotic skin and prosthetic applications, unlike traditional continuous high-rate sampling methods.

## 5. RESTORING SENSORY FEEDBACK
Sensory information plays a critical role in both the exploration of the external environment and in any manipulation task. When an individual interacts with surrounding objects, tactile sensations are used to infer features such as size, compliance, temperature, and texture, while the same sensations are exploited to handle them properly or use them as tools. From this perspective, aiming to restore afferent sensory channels from a hand prosthesis is a critical step in designing a device that ensures two key aspects: dexterous manipulation and embodiment of the prosthetic device.

The design of a sensory feedback system that can successfully deliver information relies on three fundamental blocks working together: ( a ) sensor readings, processed by ( ) an encoding b strategy capable of translating meaningful information to the user, through ( ) an interface. Prec vious sections have described the different available interfaces; here, we present the encoding techniques and sensors relevant to the design of modern hand prostheses ( Table 1 ).

Sensors mounted on a robotic hand should ideally record the whole spectrum of available human sensations, from both external and internal sources. Indeed, sensory information from the human hand covers both interactions with the external world (tactile perception, thermal perception, and nociception, i.e., perception of pain) and internal perception of the positions of the joints and the length and forces exerted by the muscles, together known as proprioception. Table 2 shows examples of sensor placements on RPHs from recent studies.
topic: Design challenges and considerations in developing sensors capable of capturing the full spectrum of human hand sensations for prosthetic applications.
question: What is the principal design challenge in developing sensors for prosthetic hands that aim to replicate the full spectrum of human hand sensations, and how does this challenge impact the effectiveness of sensory feedback for dexterous manipulation and embodiment?

choices.A: Integrating sensors that capture diverse modalities—tactile, thermal, nociceptive, and proprioceptive—and encoding their signals into meaningful feedback that the user can interpret, because incomplete or poorly encoded sensory information limits manipulation precision and user embodiment.
choices.B: Ensuring sensors are only placed on the fingertips to maximize tactile sensitivity, because concentrating sensors reduces complexity and improves feedback accuracy.
choices.C: Designing sensors exclusively focused on proprioception, as internal perception alone is sufficient for dexterous manipulation without external sensory input.
choices.D: Prioritizing thermal sensors over tactile and proprioceptive sensors, since temperature perception is the primary determinant of object manipulation success.

explanation: The main design challenge lies in capturing a broad range of sensory modalities and translating them into meaningful feedback, as the human hand’s sensory system integrates multiple types of information critical for precise control and embodiment; neglecting any modality or poor encoding reduces prosthetic effectiveness.

## 4. MOTOR CONTROL
Despite the advances in techniques for voluntary motor decoding and the increased sophistication of the available RPHs, body-powered prostheses are still the most robust control approach. The mechanism of these devices is based on a cable actuated by movements of the shoulder to control one DOF. The vast majority of commercially available RPHs use simple threshold-based sEMG decoding over a few surface electrodes and also generally control one DOF (66); in some cases, the RPH provides more DOFs, but this comes at the cost of a nonintuitive command scheme. These systems also offer no possibility to control several DOFs at the same time. The current situation is, therefore, increasingly sophisticated RPH mechanics with unchanged control strategies. As such, patients often abandon myoelectric prostheses, in part because the small functional improvement does not justify their price and complexity (13, 67).

Here, we describe recent advances in control strategies in terms of decoding type (classification or continuous control) and functional achievement (e.g., number of DOFs, grasping, or single-finger decoding) and compare them with the classical direct control approach. Section 4.1 details different algorithmic approaches to decode motor functions, with an emphasis on sEMG; Section 4.2 discusses the addition of robotic automation to improve grasp robustness; Section 4.3 compares implanted methods to extract the user's intentions; and finally, Section 4.4 presents a perspective on the broader adoption of these techniques by patients. Table 1 includes the different decoding strategies and their level of maturity.
topic: The role and integration of robotic automation in improving grasp robustness and compensating for limitations in user-driven control.
question: In the context of robotic prosthetic hands, why is the integration of robotic automation critical for improving grasp robustness, especially given the current limitations of voluntary motor decoding and user-driven control schemes?

choices.A: Because voluntary motor decoding can simultaneously control multiple DOFs intuitively, robotic automation primarily enhances prosthetic speed rather than grasp robustness.
choices.B: Because threshold-based sEMG decoding and limited DOF control in current user-driven schemes create nonintuitive command systems that hinder simultaneous multi-DOF control, robotic automation compensates by enabling more reliable and robust grasp execution.
choices.C: Because body-powered prostheses already provide robust multi-DOF control, robotic automation is mainly used to reduce device cost and complexity.
choices.D: Because implanted methods for extracting user intentions eliminate the need for any form of robotic automation to improve grasp robustness.

explanation: Current user-driven control schemes, especially those relying on simple threshold-based sEMG decoding, are limited to controlling usually one DOF at a time with nonintuitive commands, preventing simultaneous multi-DOF control and diminishing grasp reliability. Robotic automation compensates for these limitations by autonomously managing grasp stabilization and coordination, thus improving grasp robustness despite imperfect voluntary control.

## 4.1. Decoding Algorithms
The clinical standard for RPH control is based on the use of two sEMG channels, with the electrodes placed superficially on antagonist muscles. The envelope of the signal is extracted so that the user can control the closing and opening of the RPH by modulating the amplitude of their muscle contraction. When the amplitude exceeds a certain threshold, the RPH will move depending on which muscle was activated. Companies are offering more DOFs, using cocontraction to

cycle through different types of grasps (e.g., Ottobock's Michelangelo hand). However, this type of control is highly nonintuitive and gives only low dexterity to the user. An alternative to this direct control approach is based on pattern recognition methods, extracting hand-crafted features to characterize the signal in a discriminative way (e.g., the signal root mean square, wavelength, and zero crossing) and classify the type of grasp intended by the user. This solution has become robust enough to reach the market (the Coapt system and Ottobock's Myo Plus). Using 2-12 bipolar sEMG electrodes makes it possible to obtain good classification rates for different kinds of grasps, with 90-95% accuracy for 4-12 classes and up to 75% for 50 classes (68-72).

Using a similar electrode disposition and classification method, other groups showed the possibility of decoding single-finger movement using the classification of flexion or extension (73, 74). Recently, Bhagwat & Mukherji (75) showed single- and multifinger classification of 15 different movements with 99.79% accuracy. Researchers are also working on proportional control instead of classification, which makes it possible to decode several DOFs (e.g., wrist and finger movements) simultaneously and proportionally (76, 77). This type of control offers continuous position control. Several studies have also shown that single-finger proportional control is feasible, with good results (78, 79).

As an alternative, nonbiomimetic EMG decoders have been developed that rely on the subject learning inverse maps to relate motor outputs to arbitrary control variables (80). Using an abstract decoding cursor control space, subjects can learn to modulate their EMG activity to reach different targets arranged in a center-out task in order to trigger various grasping movements (81). Dyson et al. (82) recently validated these results on amputee participants; they showed that after training, the difficulty of the tasks could be increased, improving the possibilities for robotic hand control.

With only a few electrodes placed on muscles of interest, the accurate positioning of the electrodes requires anatomical knowledge; indeed, the type of amputation (congenital or traumatic), the surgical procedure, and the time since amputation (83) could influence the muscle anatomy and make the placement of the electrode tedious and specific to individual subjects. Moreover, a small shift in electrode placement can disrupt the pattern recognition algorithm (84). T o tackle these issues, several authors have proposed HD-sEMG, which consists of a grid of closely spaced electrodes, as an alternative solution. The large number of electrodes allows information to be recorded from a large part of the subject's forearm.

HD-sEMG signals offer high spatial resolution, and recorded signals can be interpreted as spatial images of EMG activity. Using this image representation of EMG data, HD-sEMG is robust to small electrode shifts (85). Boschmann & Platzner (85) used a structural similarity index, borrowed from the computer vision field, on HD-sEMG images combined with a simple one-against-one nearest-neighbor classifier to decode wrist and hand motions. Similarly, Stango et al. (86) used a variogram of images (a measure of the degree of spatial correlation, used mainly in geostatistics) to classify wrist movements. Both groups showed that their methods, which use spatial information from the images, performed better or similarly to the classic feature extraction approach. Moreover, their strategies improved the robustness to electrode shift and electrode number. The use of several spatially close electrodes makes it possible to decompose the EMG signal into its constituent motor unit action potential (50, 87). Kapelner et al. (88) investigated this approach, decomposing EMG signals to extract motor unit activity from forearm muscles during wrist motions. Recently, Dai & Hu (89) showed that an approach consisting of finger joint angle estimation, combining classification for finger selection with EMG decomposition into motor unit activity, outperforms a standard amplitude-based approach.

We observe a paradigm shift from feature engineering to feature learning using raw data as input for deep neural networks. Studies have shown that combining this deep learning approach with HD-sEMG offers better performance than hand-crafted features in both grasp classification

(90) and simultaneous single-finger and wrist movement classification (91). Deep learning has also shown good results with a smaller number of electrodes for grasp classification (72) and regression of arm or wrist motions (92, 93).

This approach permits both high dexterity and robustness, with unprecedented performance. However,one of the major difficulties of the deep learning approach is that it requires an extensive data set for training. For example, the deep learning used for the ImageNet challenge in 2012 used 1.2 million images for training on 1,000 categories (94). In the context of hand gesture recognition, generating tens of thousands of examples for a subject is not a viable option.

A possible solution could use domain adaptation [often called transfer learning in the EMG literature (95, 96)], by leveraging data acquired from several subjects to enhance and accelerate training for a new user. Indeed, the aim is to use information from a database of several source domains and adapt it to a target domain (the end user) with a small number of samples. Authors generally apply deep domain adaptation (domain adaptation combined with deep learning) by pretraining a deep neural network and fine-tuning it with a few repetitions of movements by a target subject. The main idea is that gathering the recordings of several participants can meet the necessary conditions to learn a general mapping of all users' sEMG signals.

Using this idea, Côté-Allard et al. (97) showed that their deep model was able to learn the features and significantly enhance the performance of deep networks on out-of-sample gestures. Using HD-sEMG and deep learning, Du et al. (98) also showed an unsupervised deep domain adaptation method that incrementally learns from data during a new session without explicit calibration of gestures. Consequently, deep learning offers a particularly attractive context from which to develop deep domain adaptation algorithms to leverage interuser data. This approach can increase decoding performance, improve robustness to electrode shift, and reduce the number of repetitions needed during training (99).

As seen in this section, the search for new EMG decoding algorithms that go beyond thresholdbased detection is an active field of research. Phinyomark & Scheme (100) and Khamparia & Singh (101) have reviewed recent research in EMG pattern recognition methods.

Machine learning in the field of computer vision and object recognition has shown outstanding results using deep learning and is already used commercially by many companies. Some deep learning algorithms based on a pretrained network are now usable without any fine-tuning (e.g., self-driving cars). However, bio-signals are intrinsically different from images and need adaptation. More important, the amount of labeled EMG data available to effectively train deep networks might not be sufficient to capture the evolution of the signal over time (electrode displacement, skin impedance changes, etc.). Therefore, if model architectures and data processing are tailored for bio-signal applications and take into consideration signal evolution with time, deep learning can become a solution for more robust motor intention decoding.
topic: Advances in decoding single-finger and multi-finger movements using classification and proportional control techniques.
question: In the context of decoding single-finger and multi-finger movements for prosthetic hand control, how does the integration of high-density sEMG (HD-sEMG) with deep learning-based feature learning fundamentally address the limitations of traditional classification approaches, and what are the primary challenges that still constrain this integration in practical clinical applications?

choices.A: HD-sEMG with deep learning improves robustness to electrode shifts and enables simultaneous proportional control of multiple degrees of freedom, but requires extensive labeled datasets and anatomical expertise for electrode placement.
choices.B: HD-sEMG with deep learning reduces the need for electrode placement precision and data volume by using hand-crafted features, yet lacks the capability for single-finger movement classification.
choices.C: HD-sEMG combined with traditional threshold-based control allows intuitive direct control of grasps with minimal training but suffers from low dexterity and poor robustness to signal variability.
choices.D: HD-sEMG with deep learning eliminates the need for any training data through unsupervised learning and fully automates electrode placement, but cannot decode proportional finger movements.

explanation: The integration of HD-sEMG provides high spatial resolution signals less sensitive to electrode placement shifts, which when combined with deep learning's ability to learn features directly from raw data, surpasses traditional hand-crafted feature classification methods in accuracy and robustness. However, this approach demands large labeled datasets for training, which are difficult to obtain in clinical settings, and precise anatomical knowledge for electrode placement remains a challenge. Domain adaptation techniques help mitigate data scarcity, but practical issues like signal non-stationarity over time persist.

topic: The importance of closed-loop control systems combining motor command decoding and sensory feedback for enhanced prosthetic hand dexterity.
question: Why does integrating both motor command decoding and sensory feedback in a closed-loop control system fundamentally enhance the dexterity of prosthetic hands compared to motor command decoding alone?

choices.A: Because sensory feedback enables the prosthesis to autonomously correct its motor commands without user intervention.
choices.B: Because sensory feedback provides real-time afferent information that allows the user to adjust motor output, resulting in more precise and natural manipulation.
choices.C: Because motor command decoding alone provides sufficient control, and sensory feedback mainly improves cosmetic appearance.
choices.D: Because sensory feedback replaces the need for motor command decoding by directly controlling prosthetic movements through reflexes.

explanation: Integrating sensory feedback in closed-loop prosthetic control provides the user with real-time tactile and proprioceptive information, enabling conscious adjustment of motor commands, which enhances precision and naturalness of hand movements; motor decoding alone lacks this afferent information, limiting dexterity.

## SKIN MECHANORECEPTORS
The skin has four types of mechanoreceptors, which are sensitive to different stimuli and therefore involved in different sensory functions: Merkel disks (which sense skin indentation, fine touch, and texture perception), Ruffini capsules (which sense skin stretch), Pacinian corpuscles (which sense vibration), and Meissner corpuscles (which sense dynamic deformation and slipperiness). Merkel disks and Ruffini capsules are slow-adapting receptors, meaning that they fire continuously during tactile stimuli, with a firing rate related to the pressure applied in their receptive field. Pacinian corpuscles and Meissner corpuscles are fast-adapting receptors that respond mostly to changes in applied pressure or brief stimuli.

low price, light weight, and easy maintenance. This type of prosthesis is also well suited for highintensity work due to the control robustness. Also, because the subject must move their shoulder to open and close the hook, these systems have inherent proprioception feedback (9). However, one of the major limitations of the hook solution is the low level of dexterity and nonanthropomorphic appearance. Body-powered hands have solved the anthropomorphic aspect while keeping the robustness of body-powered solutions (10). For example, Baril et al. (11) developed a programmable body-powered hand that can perform different grasp types using a mechanical selector that blocks the closing of one or more fingers. Nevertheless, this solution has its drawback as well: Because of their low mechanical efficiency, body-powered prostheses require large amounts of energy (from 33 N for a hook to 131 N for a hand) to produce a relatively low pinch force (15 N) (12). This could explain their high rejection rate by patients, which ranges between 16% and 66% depending on the survey and time period (13).

Here, we concentrate on RPHs because they potentially offer the most versatile, natural, and power-efficient replacement for amputated hands and could become the default solution for patients. We investigate the challenges in existing RPHs, considering both commercially available solutions ( Supplemental Table 1 ) and those in the research phase ( Supplemental Table 2 ).

Mimicking the biomechanics of a hand is not easy. Early prototypes (14) succeeded in designing fingers with skeleton-like structures, but biomimetic actuation was only recently properly implemented using muscle-like actuators (15). The challenge for RPH developers is to embed actuators, sensors, and electronic components into a prosthesis with the same size and weight as the replaced hand (14, 16, 17). Major system integration and miniaturization are necessary before these systems can be used by amputee patients.

Instead, underactuation is a widespread approach to simplify the mechanics while keeping reasonable dexterity. An underactuated system is one where the number of degrees of actuation (DOAs) is smaller than the number of DOFs (see DOA/DOF < 1 in Supplemental Tables 1 and 2 ). The passive (nonactuated) DOFs are exploited to adapt to the surface in contact, as suggested by the concept of morphological computation (18), and to enable a self-adjusting grip without the need to control each articulation. These systems reduce the number of motors needed in the RPH and therefore its complexity, weight, and price.
topic: Compare the energy requirements and mechanical efficiency between body-powered hooks, body-powered hands, and robotic prosthetic hands.
question: How do mechanical efficiency and energy requirements differ between body-powered hooks, body-powered hands, and robotic prosthetic hands, and what design principles underlie these differences impacting their functionality and user acceptance?

choices.A: Body-powered hooks require lower input force and have higher mechanical efficiency than body-powered hands, but both lack dexterity; robotic prosthetic hands use underactuation to reduce complexity and improve power efficiency while enhancing dexterity, which increases user acceptance.
choices.B: Body-powered hands have the highest mechanical efficiency and lowest energy requirements due to their anthropomorphic design; body-powered hooks require more energy, while robotic prosthetic hands are less efficient because of their complex actuators.
choices.C: Body-powered hooks and hands have similar mechanical efficiency and energy requirements, but robotic prosthetic hands consume the most energy due to the need for multiple fully actuated degrees of freedom without underactuation.
choices.D: Robotic prosthetic hands have the lowest mechanical efficiency and highest energy consumption because of their electronic components, while body-powered hooks and hands are more efficient but offer no proprioceptive feedback.

explanation: Body-powered hooks require about 33 N input force and body-powered hands about 131 N to produce a low pinch force (~15 N), indicating low mechanical efficiency and high energy demands, which contribute to rejection. Robotic prosthetic hands employ underactuation, reducing the number of actuators relative to degrees of freedom, thus lowering complexity and energy use while improving dexterity and control, positively influencing user acceptance.

topic: Critically assess the translation of biological tactile mechanisms into artificial stimulation techniques used in robotic prosthetics to restore touch sensation.
question: Considering the distinct sensory functions and adaptation properties of the four skin mechanoreceptors, which of the following best explains the fundamental challenge in replicating naturalistic tactile feedback in robotic prosthetic hands?

choices.A: Artificial stimulation must simultaneously mimic both slow-adapting (continuous) and fast-adapting (transient) receptor responses to convey pressure, texture, stretch, vibration, and dynamic touch modalities, which requires complex encoding strategies beyond simple pressure sensing.
choices.B: Since all mechanoreceptors respond primarily to pressure, replicating tactile feedback in prosthetics mainly involves accurately measuring static pressure levels and delivering equivalent continuous stimulation.
choices.C: The primary challenge lies in replicating only the Merkel disk receptor because it is the sole receptor responsible for all tactile sensations including vibration and stretch.
choices.D: Replicating tactile feedback is straightforward because fast-adapting receptors respond only to brief stimuli, which can be easily simulated with simple pulsed electrical stimulation without considering receptor diversity.

explanation: The four mechanoreceptors differ in stimulus specificity and adaptation rates; slow-adapting Merkel disks and Ruffini capsules respond continuously to pressure and stretch, while fast-adapting Pacinian and Meissner corpuscles respond transiently to vibration and dynamic deformation. Effective prosthetic tactile feedback must replicate these diverse responses simultaneously, which is a complex challenge beyond mere pressure sensing.

topic: The effects of amputation and prosthesis implantation on body and peripersonal space representations and their rehabilitation implications.
question: How does prosthesis implantation modulate the altered body and peripersonal space representations caused by amputation, and what are the key implications of these modulations for designing effective sensory-feedback-based rehabilitation protocols?

choices.A: Prosthesis implantation restores original body and peripersonal space representations to their pre-amputation state, enabling rehabilitation protocols to focus solely on motor retraining without sensory feedback integration.
choices.B: Prosthesis implantation partially reshapes body and peripersonal space representations by integrating multisensory inputs, implying that rehabilitation protocols must emphasize multisensory feedback to facilitate prosthetic embodiment and functional motor control.
choices.C: Prosthesis implantation does not affect body or peripersonal space representations altered by amputation; thus, rehabilitation should prioritize compensatory strategies rather than sensory feedback or embodiment.
choices.D: Prosthesis implantation disrupts residual body and peripersonal space representations further, suggesting that sensory feedback should be minimized during rehabilitation to avoid maladaptive plasticity.

explanation: Prosthesis implantation leads to partial reshaping of the amputee's body and peripersonal space representations through integration of multisensory inputs, such as visual, tactile, and proprioceptive feedback, which supports embodiment of the prosthetic limb. This neuroplastic adaptation highlights the importance of designing rehabilitation protocols that incorporate sensory feedback mechanisms to promote functional motor control and reduce phantom limb distortions.

## 4.1. Decoding Algorithms
The clinical standard for RPH control is based on the use of two sEMG channels, with the electrodes placed superficially on antagonist muscles. The envelope of the signal is extracted so that the user can control the closing and opening of the RPH by modulating the amplitude of their muscle contraction. When the amplitude exceeds a certain threshold, the RPH will move depending on which muscle was activated. Companies are offering more DOFs, using cocontraction to

cycle through different types of grasps (e.g., Ottobock's Michelangelo hand). However, this type of control is highly nonintuitive and gives only low dexterity to the user. An alternative to this direct control approach is based on pattern recognition methods, extracting hand-crafted features to characterize the signal in a discriminative way (e.g., the signal root mean square, wavelength, and zero crossing) and classify the type of grasp intended by the user. This solution has become robust enough to reach the market (the Coapt system and Ottobock's Myo Plus). Using 2-12 bipolar sEMG electrodes makes it possible to obtain good classification rates for different kinds of grasps, with 90-95% accuracy for 4-12 classes and up to 75% for 50 classes (68-72).

Using a similar electrode disposition and classification method, other groups showed the possibility of decoding single-finger movement using the classification of flexion or extension (73, 74). Recently, Bhagwat & Mukherji (75) showed single- and multifinger classification of 15 different movements with 99.79% accuracy. Researchers are also working on proportional control instead of classification, which makes it possible to decode several DOFs (e.g., wrist and finger movements) simultaneously and proportionally (76, 77). This type of control offers continuous position control. Several studies have also shown that single-finger proportional control is feasible, with good results (78, 79).

As an alternative, nonbiomimetic EMG decoders have been developed that rely on the subject learning inverse maps to relate motor outputs to arbitrary control variables (80). Using an abstract decoding cursor control space, subjects can learn to modulate their EMG activity to reach different targets arranged in a center-out task in order to trigger various grasping movements (81). Dyson et al. (82) recently validated these results on amputee participants; they showed that after training, the difficulty of the tasks could be increased, improving the possibilities for robotic hand control.

With only a few electrodes placed on muscles of interest, the accurate positioning of the electrodes requires anatomical knowledge; indeed, the type of amputation (congenital or traumatic), the surgical procedure, and the time since amputation (83) could influence the muscle anatomy and make the placement of the electrode tedious and specific to individual subjects. Moreover, a small shift in electrode placement can disrupt the pattern recognition algorithm (84). T o tackle these issues, several authors have proposed HD-sEMG, which consists of a grid of closely spaced electrodes, as an alternative solution. The large number of electrodes allows information to be recorded from a large part of the subject's forearm.

HD-sEMG signals offer high spatial resolution, and recorded signals can be interpreted as spatial images of EMG activity. Using this image representation of EMG data, HD-sEMG is robust to small electrode shifts (85). Boschmann & Platzner (85) used a structural similarity index, borrowed from the computer vision field, on HD-sEMG images combined with a simple one-against-one nearest-neighbor classifier to decode wrist and hand motions. Similarly, Stango et al. (86) used a variogram of images (a measure of the degree of spatial correlation, used mainly in geostatistics) to classify wrist movements. Both groups showed that their methods, which use spatial information from the images, performed better or similarly to the classic feature extraction approach. Moreover, their strategies improved the robustness to electrode shift and electrode number. The use of several spatially close electrodes makes it possible to decompose the EMG signal into its constituent motor unit action potential (50, 87). Kapelner et al. (88) investigated this approach, decomposing EMG signals to extract motor unit activity from forearm muscles during wrist motions. Recently, Dai & Hu (89) showed that an approach consisting of finger joint angle estimation, combining classification for finger selection with EMG decomposition into motor unit activity, outperforms a standard amplitude-based approach.

We observe a paradigm shift from feature engineering to feature learning using raw data as input for deep neural networks. Studies have shown that combining this deep learning approach with HD-sEMG offers better performance than hand-crafted features in both grasp classification

(90) and simultaneous single-finger and wrist movement classification (91). Deep learning has also shown good results with a smaller number of electrodes for grasp classification (72) and regression of arm or wrist motions (92, 93).

This approach permits both high dexterity and robustness, with unprecedented performance. However,one of the major difficulties of the deep learning approach is that it requires an extensive data set for training. For example, the deep learning used for the ImageNet challenge in 2012 used 1.2 million images for training on 1,000 categories (94). In the context of hand gesture recognition, generating tens of thousands of examples for a subject is not a viable option.

A possible solution could use domain adaptation [often called transfer learning in the EMG literature (95, 96)], by leveraging data acquired from several subjects to enhance and accelerate training for a new user. Indeed, the aim is to use information from a database of several source domains and adapt it to a target domain (the end user) with a small number of samples. Authors generally apply deep domain adaptation (domain adaptation combined with deep learning) by pretraining a deep neural network and fine-tuning it with a few repetitions of movements by a target subject. The main idea is that gathering the recordings of several participants can meet the necessary conditions to learn a general mapping of all users' sEMG signals.

Using this idea, Côté-Allard et al. (97) showed that their deep model was able to learn the features and significantly enhance the performance of deep networks on out-of-sample gestures. Using HD-sEMG and deep learning, Du et al. (98) also showed an unsupervised deep domain adaptation method that incrementally learns from data during a new session without explicit calibration of gestures. Consequently, deep learning offers a particularly attractive context from which to develop deep domain adaptation algorithms to leverage interuser data. This approach can increase decoding performance, improve robustness to electrode shift, and reduce the number of repetitions needed during training (99).

As seen in this section, the search for new EMG decoding algorithms that go beyond thresholdbased detection is an active field of research. Phinyomark & Scheme (100) and Khamparia & Singh (101) have reviewed recent research in EMG pattern recognition methods.

Machine learning in the field of computer vision and object recognition has shown outstanding results using deep learning and is already used commercially by many companies. Some deep learning algorithms based on a pretrained network are now usable without any fine-tuning (e.g., self-driving cars). However, bio-signals are intrinsically different from images and need adaptation. More important, the amount of labeled EMG data available to effectively train deep networks might not be sufficient to capture the evolution of the signal over time (electrode displacement, skin impedance changes, etc.). Therefore, if model architectures and data processing are tailored for bio-signal applications and take into consideration signal evolution with time, deep learning can become a solution for more robust motor intention decoding.
topic: Methods leveraging spatial image representations of HD-sEMG signals, such as structural similarity indices and variograms, to enhance classification performance.
question: How do spatial image representations of HD-sEMG signals, such as the structural similarity index and variograms, fundamentally enhance the robustness and classification performance of hand and wrist movement decoding compared to classical feature-based methods, particularly in relation to electrode shift and spatial correlation in the signal?

choices.A: By encoding temporal frequency components of EMG signals, they increase sensitivity to muscle fatigue variations, which improves classification.
choices.B: By capturing spatial correlations and patterns across densely spaced electrodes, they provide robustness to electrode placement variability and exploit rich spatial information unavailable to single-channel amplitude features.
choices.C: By reducing the dimensionality of EMG data through averaging across electrodes, they simplify the classification problem and minimize overfitting.
choices.D: By focusing solely on amplitude thresholds in antagonist muscles, they ensure intuitive and direct control of prosthetic hand movements with minimal training.

explanation: Spatial image representations like structural similarity indices and variograms analyze the spatial distribution and correlations of EMG activity across multiple closely spaced electrodes in HD-sEMG grids. This approach leverages spatial patterns that remain consistent despite small electrode shifts, unlike classical single-channel amplitude features that are sensitive to electrode placement. Consequently, these spatial metrics improve classification accuracy and robustness by effectively encoding richer spatial information inherent in muscle activation patterns.

topic: Comparison and evaluation of different peripheral nerve electrode technologies for selective stimulation and recording in prosthetic control.
question: Among peripheral nerve electrode technologies used for selective stimulation and recording in prosthetic control, which electrode type offers the highest selectivity for individual fascicles while balancing invasiveness and long-term stability?

choices.A: Cuff electrodes, due to their non-penetrating design that wraps around the nerve, providing moderate selectivity and high long-term stability.
choices.B: Longitudinal intrafascicular electrodes, which penetrate nerve fascicles longitudinally to enable selective interfacing but pose challenges in chronic stability.
choices.C: Utah Slanted Electrode Arrays, which penetrate perpendicularly into multiple fascicles, offering high selectivity but with increased invasiveness and potential for tissue damage.
choices.D: Surface electromyography electrodes, which are non-invasive but provide low selectivity limited to muscle-level signals rather than nerve fascicles.

explanation: Utah Slanted Electrode Arrays provide the highest selectivity by penetrating multiple fascicles perpendicularly, allowing for detailed interfacing with individual nerve fibers; however, this comes at the cost of increased invasiveness and potential tissue damage, which may affect long-term stability. Longitudinal intrafascicular electrodes also offer good selectivity but are less invasive than Utah arrays and face challenges in chronic implantation. Cuff electrodes, while minimally invasive and stable long-term, have limited selectivity as they interface extraneurally. Surface EMG electrodes are non-invasive but lack nerve-level selectivity.
